title: arlene foster wins 125000 payout defamatory tweet tvs dr christian
story: A TV doctor has been ordered to pay a record £125,000 in damages to Arlene Foster for a tweet wrongly claiming the First Minister of Northern Ireland was having an extramarital affair.Celebrity medic Dr Christian Jessen posted the tweet on Dec 23, 2019, to his 300,000-plus followers, claiming she was in an illicit relationship with her security guard. The sum of £125,000 plus costs is a record for a tweet, according to Mrs Foster's legal team.Delivering judgment in the case at the High Court in Belfast, Mr Justice McAlinden accepted that the false tweet had cut Mrs Foster to the core at a time she was leading delicate negotiations on the re-establishment of the Northern Ireland Executive.The judge said:  To state that a woman married for 25-and-a-half years and a mother of three children, who is a committed Christian and who is recognised as such, and who has publicly made statements extolling the importance and sanctity of marriage, who also happens to be the leader of the Democratic Unionist Party and a holder of the office of First Minister of Northern Ireland, was an adulterer, a hypocrite and a homophobe is a most serious libel and is grossly defamatory.It is an outrageous libel concerning an inidual of considerable standing, attacking her integrity at the most fundamental level, and it involves the trashing in a very public fashion of the relationship that Mrs Foster holds dearest in her life.It affected core aspects of her life, namely her relationship with her husband, her deep Christian faith.A key issue in the case was the TV doctor's repeated failure to engage in the legal process and respond to papers served on him by Mrs Foster's representatives.Dr Jessen, best known for his role on the Channel 4 show Embarrassing Bodies, first engaged with the legal proceedings after Mrs Foster had already given evidence to the court.He claimed he had been previously unaware the case at Belfast High Court was happening.Dr Jessen previously told the court that he had moved out of his London city centre flat at the time and into his parents' home as he was suffering from mental health issues and had not been watching the news.Speaking outside court after the ruling, Mrs Foster's solicitor Paul Tweed said: I would just say one thing personally. On Christmas Day 2019, in response to the warning I had given to Dr Jessen, he tweeted 'Laugh Out Loud'. I don't think he will be laughing too much today.  He added: My client is very satisfied with the substantial sum in damages awarded by the court today. Indeed I believe this is a record award for a tweet.The award also takes into account a number of aggravating factors in this case, including Dr Jessen's failure to retract and apologise. Dr Jessen has been offered every opportunity to do the right thing in this regard from the outset, but he has pointedly failed to do so.My client is grateful to the court for this total vindication which hopefully will also act as an encouragement and a watershed for all women in public life who have been subjected to similar attacks on social media.  Earlier, in his ruling, Mr Justice McAlinden said: The offending tweet remained on the defendant's Twitter account for two weeks, a Twitter account with 311,000 followers.The tweet was liked approximately 3,500 times and it was retweeted 517 times. The fact that the defendant failed to take down the offending tweet was the subject of mainstream media coverage.This outrageously bad libel cut her (Mrs Foster) to the core, causing her considerable upset, distress, humiliation, embarrassment and hurt.Bearing in mind the time of year and the work-related pressures the plaintiff was under at that time, I fully accept this libel took a heavy emotional toll despite her experience of dealing with the heat of robust political debate.Her marriage, her family life and her faith are the most important things in her life. These things provide important pillars of support and it was these things that were publicly trashed.Giving evidence last month, Mrs Foster told the court the incident came at a particularly stressful time when she was involved in talks to resurrect the powersharing government in the region. She said she felt the rumour of the affair with a close protection officer, which she described as having emerged online from anonymous accounts before the tweet by Dr Jessen, was designed to destabilise her at a critical time.I think the attack on me personally and my marriage was meant to destabilise me at a very critical time, she told the court.It was meant to destabilise me and thereby destabilise the negotiations as well. I have no proof of that, but I just think the timing of it is very significant given when it came.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: biting back would dilyn dog say evidence
story: Westminster is reeling. During an extraordinary seven-hour hearing in Parliament on Wednesday, the Prime Minister’s former chief adviser Dominic Cummings made a string of explosive claims about his numerous enemies in Downing Street.Many of these claims, however, are disputed. And given the seriousness of Cummings’s allegations, MPs will surely want to give each of his foes a right of reply.Roll on the next sensational hearing…Greg Clark MP: “Dilyn the Downing Street dog, thank you very much for agreeing to appear before the committee today. It’s been widely reported that, during Dominic Cummings’s time in No 10, the two of you had a working relationship that was less than harmonious. Is this the case?”Dilyn: “Thank you, Mr Chair. I’ll be absolutely frank here: the man was never fit for office. In fact, I repeatedly advised the Prime Minister to get rid of him.”Greg Clark: “And how did the Prime Minister respond?”Dilyn: “He wouldn’t listen. He just looked at me as if I was barking.”Greg Clark: “What was it about Mr Cummings that you objected to?”Dilyn: “He was just a nightmare to have around the place. Poorly behaved. Constantly getting under everyone’s feet. Always making a mess. Clearly hadn’t been house-trained. Quite frankly, I don’t know where they got him from.”Greg Clark: “When Mr Cummings appeared before this committee, he suggested that you were a hindrance to the work of Downing Street employees. According to him, Carrie Symonds ordered staff to spend their time rebutting negative coverage of you in the press, when they should have been dealing with far more important issues. Is this true?”Dilyn: “Look, all those stories about me were complete fabrications. Ever since I entered Downing Street, I have been the subject of a concerted smear campaign, clearly designed to undermine my position. And the press office had a duty to correct the record, so the public could see that these allegations about me were wholly unfounded.”Dilyn: “One, that the Prime Minister found me chewing a priceless antiquarian book at Chequers, and had to free it from my jaws. This is a total misrepresentation. In reality, I was simply bringing the book to the Prime Minister, because it was a classic treatise on the art of statesmanship, and I believed it contained valuable advice from which the PM could benefit. He accepted the book gratefully, and promised to add it to the top of his bedside reading pile.”Greg Clark: “But according to the account in the press, the Prime Minister shouted: ‘Someone please shoot that dog’.”Dilyn: “Again, this is an outrageous twisting of the truth. The Prime Minister meant ‘shoot’ as in ‘take photographs of’. He believed that publishing some charming pictures of his beloved pet would boost the public’s morale at a time of national crisis.”Greg Clark: “Who do you believe to have been the source of these briefings against you?”Dilyn: “There’s no doubt in my mind at all. From day one, it was obvious that Mr Cummings viewed me as a rival.”Dilyn: “He could see that I had the Prime Minister’s ear. Contrary to reports in the media, however, I was affectionately nibbling it – not biting. At no point did I draw blood.”Greg Clark: “You’ve made clear to this committee that you consider Mr Cummings to be an unreliable witness. Do you dispute his claim that, during a discussion in No 10 last year about whether to impose another lockdown, the Prime Minister said: ‘Let the bodies pile high’?”Dilyn: “Once again, this is an appalling misrepresentation. What the Prime Minister actually said was: ‘Let the Boddies pile high’ – as in, cans of Boddingtons Bitter. He was simply inviting everyone at the meeting to discuss the matter further over a few beers. It had been a long evening, and he wanted his advisers to let their hair down, enjoy a drink or two, and then resume the discussion. It was a perfectly innocent remark – and yet it’s been deliberately twisted to make the Prime Minister look bad.”Greg Clark: “Mr Cummings also told the committee that he quit Downing Street because the Prime Minister’s ‘girlfriend’, fiancée Carrie Symonds, was ‘trying to change a whole bunch of appointments at No 10’. According to him, she wished to ensure that those closest to her were given top jobs. Is this true?”Dilyn: “Absolute nonsense. The process by which I was offered the role of Downing Street press secretary was entirely above board. I declined purely because I wished to focus on other interests, such as chewing my tennis ball and chasing the squirrels in St James’s Park.”Greg Clark: “Dilyn the Downing Street dog, thank you very much for your time today. Have you anything further you wish to tell the committee?”Dilyn: “The problem in this crisis was that it was lions led by donkeys. Whereas the lions should obviously have been led by dogs.”More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: can take mask now confusion reigns vaccinated americans
story: This first appeared in the Letter from the USA newsletter. Sign up for expert insight and exclusive analysis on American politics, written every Thursday here.A few days ago I went to my local supermarket in a suburb of Washington.There was a sign on the door saying that, on the advice of the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, masks are no longer required inside if you're fully vaccinated.More than half of adults in America, including myself, are now completely jabbed up.So I was surprised to discover that I was the only person in the store not wearing a mask.I've since been to two more shops, including a monster-sized outlet called Target. Both of those stores, also on the advice of the CDC, do not require masks to be worn.Yet, on each occasion, everyone I saw inside - customers and staff - was still wearing them.On my way out of one shop I overheard two men talking about having had no ill effects after their second jabs. Yet they were both still wearing masks. In the car park.So what's going on here? Well, it appears a significant number of fully vaccinated Americans are needlessly wearing soggy cloths on their faces weeks after their own government told them they don't have to.On May 13, in a blaze of publicity, the CDC announced masks were no longer needed, indoors or out, if you are fully vaccinated.Today is a great day for America,” Joe Biden declared in the White House Rose Garden, removing his own face covering. If you are fully vaccinated, you no longer need to wear a mask.Dr Rochelle Walensky, the CDC Director, said: We have all longed for this moment.Apparently, some were longing for it more than others.Far be it from me to suggest that my fellow vaccinated shoppers take their masks off. If someone wants to carry on wearing one until 2030 just in case that’s their right.But it just seems bonkers. When the foremost experts and the President have told you Hey, it’s OK to take it off now then why wouldn’t you?Maybe the message is taking time to get through. Although given the publicity that seems unlikely.Perhaps it’s just inertia, that mask wearing has become a habit. People have also been scared, and might just want to be doubly sure the pandemic really is over.Or, maybe they want to show solidarity with those who aren’t vaccinated. But if that’s the case it doesn’t make sense.If you want to encourage others to get jabbed, the best thing would be to remove your mask in the supermarket aisle, jump up and down on it, and shout Look at me. I've been vaccinated. I'm free.As America's most trusted coronavirus expert Dr Anthony Fauci explained, the CDC's decision to lift mask requirements for vaccinated people was fully intended to serve as an incentive for those who have been reluctant to get the vaccine.There is another possibility. The question of whether vaccinated people can still spread the virus at a low level is not definitively answered, and some Americans may be cautious about that.But the CDC has concluded it is safe for vaccinated people to roam around stores maskless. And the CDC knows what the risk is better than those who shop at Target.It is worth noting that mask wearing has always varied widely across America.At the height of the pandemic I went into a supermarket in the southern state of Georgia. All the people I could see were not wearing masks.Now, as the crisis moves towards its conclusion, the opposite is true in and around Washington - people are inexplicably refusing to ditch them.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: dealings switzerland eu proving us right leaving
story: Was the UK government a difficult customer when it came to negotiating a trade deal with the EU? No doubt Michel Barnier would want us to believe so - with his complaints about cherry-picking and wanting our cake and eating it. But the collapse of trade talks between the EU and Switzerland tells a different story.  Switzerland, which once filed an application to join the EU but never went along with it, has rubbed along for years quite happily on the back of a wad of bilateral trade agreements with the bloc – around 120 of them. Through those agreements it has functioned as a member of the single market, though remains outside the EU customs union - which allows it to do its own trade deals with third countries. For the Swiss it is a best-of-both-worlds arrangement - a model which was at one time touted as a possible blueprint for Britain’s post-Brexit relationship with the EU, although dismissed by the May government as it would have meant Britain remaining under the jurisdiction of the EU Court of Justice.  But this happy arrangement is about to be phased out - thanks to the EU trying to muscle its way into Swiss affairs in a way the Swiss found unacceptable. It started with the EU, eight years ago, wanting to roll those 120 bilateral trade agreements into one. It was a reasonable ambition you might think - a tidying-up exercise, a rationalisation which would make the rules easier for everyone to understand.But, needless to say, that wasn’t just what the EU had in mind. It wanted to seize the opportunity to extend its free movement rules to Switzerland and more effectively to impose its regulations on the country. In future, Switzerland was to be forced into ‘dynamic alignment’ with EU regulations. In other words, the EU would lay down the rules that it expected Switzerland to follow, on environmental law, labour law and everything else. Moreover, it expected Switzerland to bend to its social security rules, which, so the Swiss feared, would have meant EU citizens being able to settle in Switzerland and gain full access to its welfare system from day one.This was one of the main points on which David Cameron’s ill-fated attempt to renegotiate Britain’s relationship with the EU in 2015 failed. The EU refused to adjust its rules, even though they made it very difficult and expensive for a country, like Britain, with a universal benefits system to obey. When, say, a citizen of a relatively poor country like Romania can turn up and be eligible, from day one, for the same social benefits as a British citizen who has been working and paying taxes here for 40 years, it is asking for trouble.Not unreasonably, the Swiss, too, have decided that they won’t accept the EU trying to demand full access to its social security system and to deny the country the ability to make its own laws. It has withdrawn from the trade talks. That doesn’t mean Switzerland will fall into a ‘no deal’ situation as the 120 bilateral agreements will remain in place, but one by one they risk becoming obsolete as the EU ups its regulation and freezes out Swiss competition.There is a very clear conclusion to draw from the episode: trade arrangements which the EU found perfectly acceptable 20, 30, 40 years ago it no longer finds acceptable. The EU no longer simply wants free trade: it wants to muscle its way into many more aspects of its neighbours’ economic and social lives. Either you are a member of the EU, it is asserted, or we will try all we can to force you to become a de facto member.In taking this attitude, the EU is threatening free trade altogether. It is much easier to do a free trade deal if you are not trying to poke your nose into every aspect of the other country’s affairs. Remainers told us that we would never have the might to do trade deals on our own – we needed to be part of the EU.Yet the Swiss episode - eight years of negotiations for nothing - tells us something quite different. Over the coming years a nimbler, less-demanding Britain has the opportunity to open up trade with the rest of the world much more successfully than has the EU. Indeed, with its growing protectionism and arrogance, the EU risks going backwards.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: exclusive micro aggressions list mistake admits cambridge vice
story: Cambridge’s vice-chancellor has moved to quell a free speech revolt by issuing a statement to academics saying the university’s publication of a “micro-aggressions” list was a mistake.Prof Stephen Toope wrote to the entire staff body to explain that aspects of its new reporting website - which was launched last week but then taken offline days later following its exposure in The  - had been included “in error”.His intervention came after 25 Cambridge dons openly rebelled over the website, signing a joint letter to this newspaper warning that academics must have “unfettered freedom of speech”.Last week, a list of potential offences were published by Cambridge on a new website on which academics and students could anonymously report “inappropriate” behaviour.It stated that academics could be committing a “micro-aggression” if they raise an eyebrow, give backhanded compliments, turn their backs on certain people, or refer to a woman as a girl.On Monday, the university performed an abrupt about-turn and took the website down.Two days later Prof Toope told staff: “Unfortunately, the supporting website contained material that was published in error. The erroneously published content included definitions and examples of behaviours that might be reportable.”He said that “some of those definitions and examples went beyond the policies discussed and agreed by colleagues” in the run-up to the website’s launch, adding: “That material should not have been there, and its publication was a mistake.”The vice-chancellor insisted that he “unambiguously” wants to “bolster the university’s reputation for enquiry and vigorous debate”.Prof Toope went on to say that Cambridge is “rightly known for offering people the space to think and to challenge conventions”.He said that the “mis-step” created the impression that the university might be “unduly” constraining freedom of expression.Dons described the personal letter from the vice-chancellor as a surprising development, with one adding: “It is unusual to have such a long email on one topic that in fact concedes the cock-up”.Another academic said: “It is obviously pretty embarrassing that the university has been planning this major new policy for over a year and they have had to do a U-turn within a week of it being launched.“It raises questions about how anything like this could have come within a mile of being approved by senior people at the university and published on their website.”He said it is “hard to believe” the material was published by mistake, “given how much work went into it”.Dr Arif Ahmed, a lecturer in philosophy at Gonville and Caius welcomed the vice-chancellor’s climb down, but said it is important to “get to the bottom” of what happened.“I think anything that involves anonymous reporting that is used for anything other than statistical process is so clearly contrary to ordinary rules of process,” he said.Dr James Orr of Cambridge’s Divinity Faculty said: “The vice-chancellor should be commended for doing the right thing.“But until the university's managers recognise that the free expression of many reasonable and plainly lawful beliefs can always be subjectively - and therefore unverifiably - construed as causing psychological harm, these sorts of crises will continue to occur.”The website had been created as part of a “Change the Culture” initiative that includes a series of policies and resources aimed at “clarifying expectations” about behaviour.A list of examples of micro-aggressions was provided on the website, including asking someone “where are you really from?” and misgendering a person, especially if they have already shared their pronouns.   This is the second free speech victory Cambridge dons have claimed in the past six months.On Thursday, Cambridge re-published its Report and Support website but the list of “micro-aggressions” had been taken down, as had its definition of racism. The website says that students and staff can make “named reports” about inappropriate behaviour of others but explained that the anonymous reporting option is now under review. It explained that a working group has been convened to decide on the future of this aspect of the site. In December, academics prevailed after voting down an attempt by university chiefs to force them to be “respectful of the erse identities of others”.Three amendments, put forward by academics who said they wanted to safeguard free speech at the 800-year-old university, were voted through, leading the rebel dons to claim they had “won by a landslide”.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: left rabid dog life like ordinary belarusians trapped country
story: Europe and Britain have moved to ban flights to and from Belarus to punish Alexander Lukashenko for effectively hijacking a Ryanair flight in order to arrest a dissident journalist. But many Belarusians who oppose Mr Lukashenko and have suffered under his rule fear they are about to become even more isolated. Maxim, a 33-year-old artist currently living at an artists residence in Vienna, was due to fly back home to Minsk next month but now is not sure how he would get back.“Minsk airport used to be the only way to get out of the country,” said Maxim, a 33-year old artist who was meant to fly back to Minsk after completing a residency in Vienna next month. “The EU ban for Belavia is a direct blow against ordinary people and civil society. They have isolated and left us with a rabid dog,” he said, referring to the president of 26 years. The regime doesn’t give a damn about Belavia because they have been slapped with visa bans as it is.”In a list of sanctions announced on Tuesday, the European Council called on member states to close their airspace and airports to Belarusian carriers, and stop their own airlines from flying to or over Belarus. Latvia and Poland (along with non-EU members Britain and Ukraine) have already banned their own airlines from flying to and from Belarus, resulting in cancelled flights to Warsaw and Riga. The measures have been welcomed by Belarusian opposition leaders including Svetlana Tsikhanouskaya, the exiled former presidential  candidate who many Belarusians believe was the legitimate winner of August's election. Speaking to the European Parliament on Thursday, she urged MEPs to stick to the proposed sanctions and not be tempted to return to a softly-softly policy. “The EU approach of gradually elevating pressure on the Lukashenko regime hasn't managed to change its behaviour and only led to a growing sense of impunity and massive repressions,“ she said. But many ordinary Belarusians, including those sympathetic to the opposition, have expressed dismay. The Belarusian government imposed stiff restrictions on crossing the country’s land borders citing fears of Covid-19 that Mr Lukashenko otherwise routinely dismisses as insignificant, making it almost impossible to drive or take the train into neighbouring Poland and Lithuania. And the recent arrests of several Belarusian dissidents in Russia, which has a visa free regime with Belarus and has previously served as an escape route for opponents of Mr Lukashenko, has also left many wary of travelling via Moscow. Many fleeing Mr Lukashenko’s brutal crackdown on the opposition have in recent months taken the short flight to Warsaw or Vilnius instead, and they now fear that door closing.“People on both sides of the border found themselves in a cage,” said Volha Neskladovskaya-Tereshkova, 28, who moved to Poland with her family in March.Everyone opposed to the Lukashenko regime “has been waiting for harsh sanctions for so long: But now that it happened, the sanctions are not really against the regime but against ordinary people,” she said. Ms Neskladovskaya-Tereshkova is typical of thousands of opposition-leaning Belarusians who have sought refuge in Europe following the terrifying and indiscriminate crackdown Mr Lukashenko unleashed after a disputed elections in August. Her husband, an IT specialist, was grabbed by riot police at an election-night protest and was repeatedly beaten and humiliated in custody before he was released three days later. Investigators declined to open a criminal probe when he complained about the beatings. The couple and their toddler left the country when secured a Polish work visa. Now, she says, she has no idea when she will next see her parents. She’s also not sure what to do about the family corgi, which is still in Minsk and which her brother was meant to bring to Warsaw in the coming weeks. “We’d probably have to do it via Russia but it’s not easy flying with a dog.”“It feels like a trap.  Land borders are closed and now planes won’t fly. In the past, if you were in danger, you could relocate to Poland or Lithuania, and the flights were cheap, fast and open to us, said  Marina Sokolova, a 46-year old freelance journalist in Minsk. Nonetheless, she insisted she could see the point of the sanctions and said she could bear them - provided all these steps contribute to change in Belarus.I’m a journalist and many of my friends are now in prison and what are our inconveniences caused by the ban in comparison to their suffering in prison. It is a double edged sword. We are trapped but we understand that this is one step to our freedom,” she said.  The anger is also spilling onto social media, with many wondering how isolation will harm the regime. Talks around passenger flights tofrom Belarus are a celebration of human indifference, Andrey Vozyanov, a Minsk based musician, wrote on Facebook. Belarusians whom I know had long feared of being sealed off, but few expected it coming from outside.European diplomats are certainly aware of the issue. German officials raised the possible impact on members of the Belarusian opposition trying to get out of the country during the talks that led up to Tuesday's statement on sanctions. And a French proposal to sever all land transportation links with Belarus was shot down by other nations who considered it too drastic and likely to hurt ordinary people. The full closure of EU airports to Belavia, the national carrier most Belarusian travellers rely on, will only come into effect after ministers and bureaucrats hammer out the legal details, which could take weeks. Minsk airport continued to schedule Belavia flights to and from EU destinations including  Amsterdam, Milan, Tallin, Vienna and Warsaw remained scheduled on Wednesday and Thursday. Flights will continue to Russia and most other former Soviet states remain unaffected, as well as major non-European hubs including Istanbul. Belavia currently flies non-stop from London Gatwick to Minsk three times weekly on an Embraer 195. A total of 13 flights from London to Minsk (one way) are scheduled to depart in June 2021, according to Cirium, a company that collates aviation industry data. Andrei Sannikov, a former presidential candidate and opposition leader who fled Belarus after being beaten and jailed in 2011, said concerns about the consequences for ordinary people were legitimate. But he argued that the measures were necessary and marked a long overdue recognition that more than two decades of trying to engage with Mr Lukashenko's regime had failed. “Yes I am worried about the impact on ordinary people, but I have not heard anyone really complaining about it so far. When I speak to people, they generally say they are willing to endure a little pain if they can finally get rid of this psychopath,” he said by telephone from Warsaw, where he now lives. The main thing is that Europe has finally realised Lukashenko is a threat to everyone. They previously tried to treat Belarus as a humanitarian issue, not as a security issue, and that did not work, he said. Ms Neskladovskaya is not so sure. “Europe wants to ensure safety for its own citizens: but who’s going to ensure our safety? she said. People got shut out and they have no idea how to get out of the country if they need to.”More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: mad herd immunity ever taboo phrase
story: Just like gravity, herd immunity is a scientific fact. To the shock of many infectious disease epidemiologists, politicians, some media, and scientists turned it into a dirty word. Some talked about a ‘herd immunity strategy,’ but every strategy leads to herd immunity, so that is as nonsensical as pilots using a ‘gravity strategy’ to land a plane. The plane will reach the ground no matter what the key is to land safely. In the Commons,  health secretary Matt Hancock tragically claimed that focused protection of the old was impossible and that “herd immunity cannot be reached”. In The Lancet, a group of scientists argued against a ‘so-called herd immunity approach’, falsely asserting that ‘there is no evidence for lasting protective immunity to SARS-CoV-2 following natural infection.’ This is contrary to the scientific evidence, as there is evidence of long-lasting immunity for recovered COVID patients. Jeremy Corbyn described a “herd immunity strategy” as a form of “eugenics,” displaying a profound lack of understanding of both concepts.Boris Johnson’s former advisor, Dominic Cummings, denounced the UKs delay in initiating lockdowns as motivated by “herd immunity.” More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: matt hancock backbenchers flock health secretarys aid spartacus
story: On Wednesday, Dominic Cummings described his work-day from hell: Covid cases surging, emergency COBRA meetings derailed by begging requests to join Trump’s bombing campaign of Iraq – and most shocking of all - Number 10’s media operation going into meltdown over the reputation of a Jack Russell.Most of us would be hard-pushed to imagine so awful a day – but then again, most of us aren’t Matt Hancock. Given the epic monstering he endured at Cummings’s hands on Wednesday, it was almost a surprise to see him still standing in the Commons, bloodied but unbowed.Caught in the crosshairs, he attempted a Churchillian call to arms – though this being Matt, it was overlaid with trademark Hancockian schmaltz. He heaped praise on Our NHS and warmly thanked the “volunteers who stood in cold car parks with a smile”.“We have come together, and we have overcome!”, he finished, flopping back dramatically on the green benches.Jonathan Ashworth, Hancock’s mild-mannered opposite number, usually seems a bit too polite for the Westminster swamp. Today, even he came out keen to slash and burn – though with his cherubic features and reedy voice, the effect was underwhelming, like watching your pet hamster attempting a powerplay to commandeer the seedbox.“Is he ashamed that he promised a protective shield around care homes, and over 30,000 care home residents have died?”, piped Ashworth solemnly.The Health Secretary looked cowed. Any minute now his bottom lip was going to wobble. But suddenly reinforcements arrived in the reassuring form of Jeremy Hunt – former health secretary, select committee chair and classic Head Boy material. Like a protective older brother, he defended poor Matt from the sixth-form bully who’d stolen his dinner money and spread nasty stories about him in the locker-room.The Tory faithful whinnied approvingly, but it was not over yet.Martyn Day of the SNP demanded a full and immediate public inquiry, Yasmin Qureshi asked about corporate manslaughter and Munira Wilson doubled down on care home deaths. Legions of opposition MPs surrounded the Health Secretary, drawn to the Cummings standard.Then, following Jeremy Hunt’s lead, the Tory backbenchers linked arms and formed a defensive phalanx around him. One by one, they stood up, in a blue-rosetted version of Spartacus, demonstrating their solidarity in ever-more sycophantic ways.“When it comes to the Health Secretary, I’m a fan”, said Mark Logan, quoting an approving constituent and plugging an article he had written in the Secretary of State's defence.“Yeahyeahyeah!” snarled the Tory combatants.Much of the love-bombing emanated from the West Country. Selaine Saxby thanked him for visiting North Devon district hospital and condemned the ‘flip-flopping’ opposition. Cherilyn Mackrory went one further, not just celebrating his trip to the Royal Cornwall Hospital in Truro but posing a hardball question: “Can my right honourable friend assure me that he will ignore unsubstantiated Westminster gossip, and stay focused on delivering the vaccination rollout?”“I’m Matt Hancock!” “I’m Matt Hancock!” they cried.It resembled siege warfare. The Opposition trebuchet would lob a few Cummings projectiles at the keep. Meanwhile Matt or one of his backbenchers would retaliate with missiles of their own, usually praise for the vaccination rollout, or use of the word ’unprecedented’, which was deployed in unprecedented quantities, even for these unprecedented times.The congenial back-slapping atmosphere occasionally intensified into heavy-petting, but Matt swelled and his confidence blossomed.At the evening press conference later, the transparency-loving Health Secretary swerved queries about care home deaths with a familiar tactic repeating the same waffling platitudes until it was time for the next question.“Every day we are unwavering in our focus to protect life”, he trilled, on auto-pilot, using phrases only a character in a Steven Spielberg film – or a Minister who knows he’s lived to fight another day – would be bold enough to articulate.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: mediterranean caribbean islands front race join green list
story: A small band of Mediterranean, Atlantic and Caribbean islands could make it onto the Government’s green list for quarantine free holidays, according to two independent analyses.Robert Boyle, a former BA strategist who correctly forecast a handful of countries last time, suggests just Malta, Finland, Slovakia and some Spanish and Greek islands will join the green list for take-off on June 7.Paul Charles, chief executive of travel consultancy The PC Agency, who also correctly identified contenders last time, suggests Malta, Grenada, Finland, the Canary Islands, Balearics, Barbados and Jamaica should all be added to the green list.Both have sought to emulate the analysis prepared for ministers by the Joint Biosecurity Centre, which provides a risk assessment on countries based on their infection rates, the prevalence of variants, their testing and genome sequencing capacity and vaccination levels.Both agree that the major European destinations of Spain, Greece, Italy and France are unlikely to make the cut on June 7 for the green list, which allows holidaymakers to return without having to quarantine, although they still have to pay for PCR tests.Only Portugal and Gibraltar in Europe are currently on the list, which currently includes 12 countries and territories such as Israel and Iceland.However, Spain, Italy, Greece and Croatia have opened their borders to British holidaymakers despite the countries being on the UK's amber list, thus requiring travellers to quarantine for 10 days on their return.Mr Boyle said seven other countries could be classified green if the EU threshold for case rates of 75 per 100,000 was used instead of the UK Government's more stringent measures. Five of these are in the EU: Austria, the Czech Republic, Germany, Italy and Luxembourg.The other two are Russia, which would be unlikely to be included for political reasons, and the United States, which has similar infection rates to Portugal and some of the highest vaccination levels in the world.Putting the US on the green list would be massive news, but with the Government under fire for failing to put India on the red list early enough, I suspect they’ll want to be seen to be taking a cautious line, said Mr Boyle.So the US is likely to just miss the cut this time round. But I do think it will be hard to find rational grounds to exclude it at the following review point later in June, unless variants of concern provide the excuse.On the down side, his assessment suggested Bahrain, Costa Rica, Trinidad and Tobago and Kuwait could be added to the red list, banning foreign travel and requiring returning Britons to quarantine in a Government approved hotel for ten days at a cost of £1,750.Grant Shapps, the Transport Secretary, has said the Government will look at the possibility of opening up to islands like the Balearics, Canaries and those in Greece with direct flights from the UK, even if infection rates prevent mainland Spain and Greece being added to the green list.Mr Charles said analysis of the rates suggested they should be green, but there may be other considerations such as the impact on UK borders where officers have to check all returning passengers. Before the pandemic five million Britons travelled to the Balearics each year.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: might soon live 150 good thing
story: “Immortality dashed,” announced the headline in this newspaper, “but humans could live to be 150.” It says something about the unrealistic expectations of the modern human that living for one and a half centuries should be presented as something of an anti-climax.For years now there have been rumours that scientists, funded by Silicon Valley billionaires, were on the brink of solving death altogether. But a large-scale study of elderly volunteers in America and the UK has concluded that even the best-maintained body is doomed to “progressive functional decline”. Our biological resilience cannot extend beyond 120-150 years: “the absolute limit of the human life”.Still – 150 years. That sounds good to me. Enough time to really get stuck in, but with a distant deadline to concentrate the mind. Like doing a PhD in life, instead of bluffing your way through the GCSE.Although the average global life has already more than doubled – from 47 in 1950, to 73 today – it’s still a struggle to fit everything in. In fact, living longer has made us more slow-moving, particularly when it comes to the big decisions: leaving the parental home, finding a long-term mate, becoming parents ourselves.I was 36 when I had the first of my three children, almost 14 years ago. If I were a global statistic from 1950, I’d be dead already. As it is, I sometimes find myself staring at the ceiling in the insomniac hours, calculating all the things I may miss out on because of this late start.If my children reproduce as sluggishly as me, and if I die in my seventies, like my father, I may never get to meet any of my grandchildren.It’s not the babies per se that I feel sad about it’s the thought that I won’t be able to accompany my children on this part of their adventure.There are, it must be admitted, obvious drawbacks to extending our lifes. The chances are we wouldn’t get much in the way of extra youth. By far the bulk of our additional years would be spent in a condition of extreme senectitude. What’s the point of meeting your descendants if you can only wave at them wanly from your pickling vat?It would be awful for the planet, too. John K Davis, an American philosophy professor, has run demographic models to see what extending our lives to 150 would do to the world. His research found that, even if the birth rate was limited to two children per woman, the global population would reach 21 billion by the end of this century: 10 billion more than currently projected. Mass famine, on the heels of climate disaster, would surely follow.For the sake of our grandchildren, then, we should not strive to meet them. But how can we resist? Life really does feel so short as it is.American pharmacists are reporting a surge in sales of teeth-whitener, as the country prepares to relax its guidance on mask-wearing. Make-up, party clothes, deodorant and hair-removal cream are also booming.What a bore! The one enjoyable aspect of this pandemic has been allowing myself to go entirely to seed. I haven’t worn make-up, put on high heels or even weighed myself for over a year. My body is so hairy I hardly need clothes to stay warm.I could happily stay like this – fat, furry and comfortable – forever. Or at least until I’m 150.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: shock poll puts far right afd ahead german regional elections
story: A shock poll has put the far-Right Alternative for Germany party (AfD) in first place ahead of regional elections in eastern Germany next week.An AfD victory in the state of Saxony-Anhalt would be a major upset and the worst possible start to Angela Merkel’s Christian Democrats' (CDU) campaign ahead of September’s general elections.A survey by the respected pollster Insa gave the AfD a slim lead, on 26 per cent, just ahead of the CDU on 25 per cent, ahead of the June 3 regional vote.The findings are unlikely to signal a national resurgence for the AfD — Saxony-Anhalt, in the former communist east, is something of an outlier and the party is polling badly at a national level.But an AfD victory in the final regional elections before September’s national vote would be a bitter blow for rival parties — and particularly for the CDU, which has won the state in every election since 2002.It could further shake confidence in Armin Laschet, the party’s candidate to succeed Mrs Merkel, who is stepping down following September's elections after 15 years in power.Mr Laschet, already struggling with low approval ratings, was not the grassroots choice to lead the CDU into September’s election, and he can little afford a loss now.Even if the AfD wins in Saxony-Anhalt, it is unlikely to be able to form a regional government. The poll has it well short of a majority, and all the other parties have ruled out going into coalition with it.Instead a rival coalition is likely form around the CDU in order to keep the far-Right party out of power.Reiner Haseloff, the regional CDU leader, has made it clear any form of cooperation with the AfD is a “red line” the party will not cross.“The AfD has no coalition partners, and cannot govern without them and against the CDU,” Hermann Binkert, the head of Insa, said.There was good news for the Green Party, which is set to more than double its vote from 2016 in Saxony-Anhalt, according to the Insa poll, which had it in fourth place on 11 per cent.The party has traditionally struggled in the former communist east, and a good result would be seen as evidence it can now compete in every region of Germany. The Greens briefly led the national polls this month, but they have slipped back to second, on 22 per cent behind the CDU on 26 percent.The AfD is currently in fifth place nationally on 11 per cent, short of the 12.5 per cent the party won in 2017’s general election.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

The Chancellor claimed his department’s contact with the former PM did “not occupy a lot of our overall time”, and that “it was important to look at this regardless of who was raising it with us.” MPs were left gobsmacked as Mr Sunak complained that having to declare details of lobbyists’ contact with officials might mean firms are less likely to engage with government. And a fresh row emerged over the publication of texts from a top Treasury official to former PM David Cameron as he lobbied officials on behalf of a doomed lender. Top treasury official Sir Tom Scholar refused to allow texts he sent to the David Cameron to be handed over to the Treasury Select Committee, which scrutinises the work of Mr Sunak’s department. Mr Cameron contacted Sir Tom, pleading in vain for the Government to prop up financier Greensill Capital as the Covid- pandemic took hold. Mr Cameron released his side of the chummy conversation - which he signed off Love DC. But the Treasury said Sir Tomaposs replies had been wiped, after his password was entered incorrectly on his official phone. In one of Mr Cameron’s messages to Sir Tom on March , the former PM appeared to predict a Bank of England interest rate cut five days before it was announced.  Mr Cameron wrote: “Never quite understood how rate cuts help a pandemic. Officials are legally barred from disclosing market sensitive information about changes to interest rates. Mr Cameron claimed he had been talking about an already announced VAT rate cut. And speaking to the Committee today, Sir Tom said he could not remember the subject of the discussion, but suggested it might have been to do with an emergency rate cut in the United States. But askedhe would allow Mr Cameron to provide his copy of his messages to the Committee, he refused - saying any release of the information should be controlled by the Treasury through Freedom of Information disclosures. Such disclosure could take weeks, and would allow the Treasury to redact the messages before they were released to the public. The messages that we were talking about were generated by me in on an official government device in the course of official government business, Sir Tom said. And I think itaposs appropriate that that be treated like any other part of official government business, and disclosure would have been governed through the Freedom of Information act. Sir Tom told the Committee his phone gets accidentally wiped about once a year, adding: It tends to happen after the password has been changed, which youaposre required to do at regular intervals. Both Treasury officials and Mr Sunak claimed Mr Cameron’s lobbying had been unsuccessful, and had not taken up much time. Charles Roxburgh, second permanent secretary to the Treasury, defended the Treasury’s nine meetings with the firm’s representatives. He told the Committee Mr Sunak “did not spend a lot of time on this, and I did not spend a lot of time on this, because I too was working on a lot more time-consuming and intense situations at the time, Mr Roxburgh met several times with Greensill at a time when the Government was scrambling to respond to the Covid- pandemic. After a few meetings the Treasury declined Greensillaposs attempts to be part of the Bank of Englandaposs Covid Corporate Financing Facilityscheme. Mr Sunak claimed increasing transparency on Government lobbying would make firms “reluctant” to engage with ministers, which he said would be “disappointing and damaging to the policymaking process. “If they feel that every communication with government is available to the public, they might be reluctant to engage,” he said.FOLLOW USMirrorPoliticsFollow @MirrorPoliticsCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnDavid CameronThe TreasuryBank of EnglandBanksCivil servantsInterest ratesPolitics

She loves nothing more than family time, especially days on the beach with her we Rachel and their children Ezra, four, and -month-old Freya. But for the other half of other month, Terri feels like a dferent person. The -year-old, from Worthing, West Sussex, suffers from premenstrual dysphoric disorder , which means the run-up to her period sees her personality drastically change as she becomes consumed by extreme anxiety, depression, and feelings of uncontrollable rage. She admits the condition means she struggled the sound of her young sonaposs constant talking.  She tells the Mirror: “PMDD turns me into a whole other version of myself. For half of the month Iaposm so happy, in control, and rational. Iaposm a good we, mother and friend. “And then I ovulate and itaposs like I get a second personality. I am me, and then Iaposm not me.” While most women suffer period pains, mood swings and heightened emotions during their monthly cycle, PMDD is very dferent and more extreme. It affects one in  women worldwide and is often categorised as extreme premenstrual tension . Many sufferers say their symptoms begin during the ovulation stage of their cycle - which is typically around  to  days before bleeding. Itaposs like my personality fades, I am full of anger, anxiety, depression, and paranoia. Iaposm crippled by fatigue and constantly experiencing hot flushes,” Terri explained. “I struggle to cope with the sound of my son talking non-stop. Or the sound of music on the radio. I get so easily overwhelmed and forgetful. I struggle to connect with my role as a mother, and as a partner. I feel attacked and often withdrawn. At its worst, the thoughts have been so hard to handle.”  Terriaposs debilitating disorder first reared its head after the birth of her son, Ezra, in . But the path to diagnosis and getting help for her condition has been an uphill battle for Terri, who says she’s found it hard to be taken seriously. “The GP tried to label it as postpartum depression because it started when my son was a baby. Then it was suggested that it was early menopause,” she explained. “I think it comes down to lack of knowledge, PMDD seems to be misunderstood across the board. Often I’ll hear ‘it’s just what all women go through’. “But it’s all cyclical, and that’s the defining thing about PMDD. Doctors just don’t seem to understand that I’m fine for one half of the month and not fine for the other half,” she said.  After being taunted by suicidal ideation and intrusive thoughts about her children harming themselves or her we being killed, she felt she had no other option but to seek private healthcare and in  she was finally given a diagnosis. “During one bad cycle, my brain was telling me that my baby girl was falling off the bed around ten times a night. Iaposd jump up in the startle reflex, sweating, cortisol soaring, searching the floor in the dark looking for my baby to comfort. Iaposd hear the thud of her falling, over and over. But she wasnapost even in the same room. She was safe and asleep in her cot.” Her we Rachel went out for a run at night and Terri’s crippling paranoia convinced her that Rachel had been murdered. “My brain literally played the most catastrophic realities like a film in my head. I imagined her death, her funeral, the bit where I tell our children she isnapost coming back. I was hit by this unimaginable grief for something that wasnapost even real. I stood on the doorstep in the cold, waiting for her to come home. The second I saw her I began hyperventilating and that led to a panic attack.”Teri, , shares snippets of her le on her colourful Instagram grid, sharing pictures of her grinning children enjoying days at the beach and snaps of loving embraces between her and Rachel.But in between the cheerful squares, she opens up with followers about her battle in a bid to help other women with the condition.  She said: “People with PMDD don’t just get a bit tearful, our world is dark and everyone is out to get us. We’re not just a bit irritable premenstrually, we’re full of misplaced and uncontrollable rage. “We don’t just feel down in the dumps, it’s an anxiety so intense that it’s a struggle to face the day, and a depression so heavy it feels like a mental illness.” “These things happen only after I ovulate. And then the emotional, physical, and psychological unrest resolves every time I come on my period and enter the follicular phase again. She has stressed that she has done everything in her power to make it better - including following a strict low GI diet, exercising, taking contraceptives and supplements but nothing has saved her from the crippling effects of her condition. The mum-of-two is currently taking SSRIs and has been on a waiting list for four months for an appointment with a gynaecologist to explore the route of medical menopause so her cycles are forced to stop completely. “It’s often misdiagnosed, or undiagnosed, and yet so often dictating and ruining young, healthy womenaposs mental and physical wellbeing,” she said “I have half a month to live a full le. I have two small children who I love and want to mother well, and PMDD is constantly challenging that. Iaposm  and should be in the prime of my le. Enjoying my family.”FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnMental healthPanic attacksMenopausePeriods

story: NewsCentre where young offenders were brutally abused to detain women seeking asylumPriti Patel’s cruel plan for the Medomsley Detention Centre in Country Durham opens a new chapter of suffering after a brutal double betrayal as surivivors of abuse want to see the buidings town down and refugee campaigners were promised a new approach to womens detentionmirrorShareCommentsByRos Wynne JonesReal Britain columnistMaryam Qaiser:,  MAY NewsDavid Alan Brown was violently abused at Medomsley Detention Centre in  " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeThe Medomsley Detention Centre site is barely visible from the road, and shunned by locals. Its ­red-brick buildings are haunted by its brutal past as an experiment in Margaret Thatcher’s “short, sharp shock”. For decades, the facility for young, first-time offenders, was the scene of brutal, sadistic detention, where  to -year-olds were sexually and physically abused – for which members of staff were eventually convicted. Now, Home Secretary Priti Patel has a new plan for the abandoned buildings near Consett, County Durham. A “prison-style” detention and “removal centre” for up to  women seeking asylum. The news comes as a blow to Medomsley’s survivors who want to see the buildings torn down. It is also a betrayal of refugee campaigners promised a new approach to women’s detention, at a time when concerns are growing over Home Office failures at Napier and Penally Barracks. What is your view  Have your say in the comment section  Medomsley survivor David ‘Alan’ Brown says he was sent there in  aged  for a petty crime he didn’t commit. Now a -year-old grandad, he waived his anonymity in  to give evidence against his abusers. This week, we introduced Alan to Agnes Tanoh, a refugee who is campaigning against the centre. “It is a shock, because in my opinion that place needs to be knocked down,” Alan told Agnes. “There are too many bad memories in that bad place. When I drive past or see or hear the word Medomsley, it makes me feel ill. I want to drive a crane with a big ball on the end and smash it to bits.” He shares his memories, which include being “kicked to bits” in a padded cell, “hearing bones crunch” during beatings handed out to other boys, and one boy asking him to stamp on his leg to break it, to escape a brutal PT session. Agnes, who once worked for the Ivorian MP Simone Gbagbo, we of the former president, narrowly escaped the Ivory Coast with her le in . A year earlier she was among those locked up with Mr and Mrs Gbagbo when rival politician Alassane ­Ouattara seized power following a contested election. More than , people were killed in fighting, including many of Agnes’ close friends. She was freed from prison by the UN, walked to Ghana, and fled to the UK to seek sanctuary. “I came here to save my le,” she tells Alan. “I knew the UK. I’d visited as a diplomat and sent my children to study here.” But when she asked for help, she ended up in the notorious Yarl’s Wood Detention Centre near Bedford.Like news to one of the Mirroraposs newsletters “It was so painful to be in prison again. I was taken three times to the airport to be deported. I thought death was waiting for me at the other side. I was so ­frightened, I tried to trust in God. “I finally have refugee status and am believed, after eight years repeating the same story. Why was I locked up  I still live with the stigma and pain.” At , Alan was beaten every day by Christopher Onslow, a PT instructor. He was punched in the mouth by another officer, John McGee. He knew others were being sexually abused. “They were watching us in the showers, there was something sick about the whole place,” he says. “Onslow was an animal. The weak lads, you could hear the crunch, he was hitting them so hard. It was a pure nightmare.”  Niamh Wilson of Hampson Hughes Solicitors, which represents survivors, adds: “It is shocking that these plans are even being considered. “We’ve worked with over  victims who suffered unimaginable physical and sexual abuse at Medomsley ­Detention Centre – the idea of the site being used again to imprison ­vulnerable people is appalling. I know victims we have supported agree the building needs to be torn down, not used for a further chapter of suffering.” A Home Office spokesperson said: “Immigration detention plays a crucial role in a robust immigration system and a signicant proportion of women detained are facing deportation because of criminal offences.  “The immigration removal estate is under ongoing review to ensure the Home Office has sufficient resilience, geographical footprint and capacity for the men and women it is necessary to detain for the purposes of removal, while providing value for money.” The facility at Medomsley later became Hassockfield Secure Training Centre, which closed in . It took until  for Alan to get justice. “I told the court, don’t feel sorry for these little old men – in  they were animals,” he says. “Onslow got eight-and-a-half years. I felt asI had lost eight stone getting that out of us.” Onslow, then , was found guilty of assault and wounding with intent while McGee, then , was jailed for two years and eight months for assault and misconduct in a public office. Agnes is visibly upset. “What I went through, I don’t want to happen to others who just want protection,” she says. “When they harm one lady, they harm a family, ­children. I will campaign until someone hears our cry.” Alan nods. “Fighting the ­Government is one of the hardest things you can do. They don’t listen to people like you and me. They don’t care about people like us. It took me years to get even with these people. “Never give up. Never. If you give up, they get away with it.”To sign Agnes’ petition, visit change.org and search for “women detention centre”Additional reporting Maryam QaiserFOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnPriti PatelHome OfficePrisonsCrimePoliticsImmigrationAsylum SeekersChild abuse

story: NewsCouple transform run-down caravan into dream riverside getaway for less than £,It took Nicola Harris and her husband Mark just four weekends to refit the static camper – and theyve turned it into a lavish lockdown-proof getaway for less than £,mirrorShareCommentsByRia NewmanLaurie Churchman:,  MAY NewsNicola Harris and her husband Mark spent £, transforming a caravan into an ideal holiday home " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA couple with a passion for DIY have transformed a caravan into a stunning riverside holiday home for just £,. Nicola Harris, , fell in love with the lush river views when she visited her brother in Shillingford-on-Thames, Oxfordshire, earlier this year. She and her husband Mark, , decided to buy a static caravan – and then spent under £, turning it into a dream getaway. Half the cost went towards flooring, new blinds and a plush sofa. The caravan looked a little tired when they bought it for £, earlier this year. But with just a few daysapos work, they have given the place a complete refit. Nicola said: “It was really dated, in good condition and quite clean but the décor wasn’t me at all. “I wanted a ‘fixer upper’, something I could really put my mark on. To turn the caravan into a stylish home, the couple took out the fitted sofas and side units in the living room - and then painted all the interior walls and units in the kitchen, bathroom and living room. They also removed the curtains and nets from the windows and replaced them with made-to-measure venetian blinds – and it cost just over £ for the whole van. Nicola and Mark also used stick-on metro tiles to give the kitchen and bathroom a fresher look. They scoured bargain home stores for accessories, getting their hands on lamps, mirrors and fake plants. It took just four weekends to complete the renovation. Nicola says removing the carpet was the worst job. She said: “Apparently they carpet caravans, then add the fitted furniture – so wardrobes, sofas, and even the shower cubicle had the pink carpet underneath. “I was still pulling up carpet at midnight the Sunday evening before the flooring was laid. I could have cried that night!” A local company installed the herringbone vinyl for the floor, which changed the feel of the caravan instantly, but the couple did the rest. Nicola added: “After the flooring was done, I loved seeing each room transformed with just a coat of paint and a few accessories. “I love it – every time I walk in, I smile – it’s such a lovely place to be. “I’m really looking forward to creating wonderful memories down the van with friends and family, especially now we can start socialising again.” The van is just  minutes away from the coupleaposs Oxfordshire home. They said it was important for the family to have a nearby vacation spot as lockdown restrictions ease. Nicola said: “With overseas travel restrictions still in place who knows when we will be able to travel freely again. “We have a two-week holiday booked to the Dominican in July but I’m pretty certain it will be cancelled so we will spend at least one, possibly two, of those weeks here at the van. “The caravan will also be nice for my grown-up children to use with their friends for a getaway, as we have all had holidays cancelled over the last  months. “With the van being right on the river, it really does have a holiday vibe to it.“Although we can’t guarantee the weather in England, when the sun does shine thereaposs no better place to be.She added: Itaposs made me look more at holidaying in England in the future, rather than feeling I always have to jet off somewhere for a break.”FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnDream Homes

The excavation project was sparked after a TV crew reported finding blue material buried in the cellar in Gloucester. It was long suspected Fred West killed the teenager and could have buried her in the basement of the then Pop In cafe in . The -year-old worked at the Pop In café, where Fred was a regular, and her disappearance came at a time when he was abducting, raping and murdering girls and women in Gloucester. But on Thursday Gloucestershire Police announced the dig had been completed and no aposhuman remains or items of signicanceapos had been found.  Police have also said the mystery aposblue materialapos was a burst pipe likely caused by the drilling of the TV production company.The search started after It gained the footage by inserting a camera into a hole their crew had drilled. Assistant Chief Constable Craig Holden said initial imagery detected something blue - but on analysis was most likely detritus or debris from a burst pipe - possibly caused by the drilling. Speaking outside Gloucestershire Constabulary he said: The blue material photographed on an endocope camera by the TV production company was not identied, but we did establish it was likely to be connected to a buried pipe. That pipe [which was not blue] was recovered and excavations went beyond the original endoscope depth. We believe that the drilling may have gone through the pipe and created some sort of detritus or debris, which is what the endoscope picked up.  When we looked, we didnapost see anything blue, so what we believe is that the imagery has given the impression of something blue. Weaposve eliminated that whatever it was that could have been interpreted as blue in that imagery from our investigation. ACC Holden confirmed the cost of the excavation to the taxpayer currently stands at around £, - but could rise to £, or £,. On raising the hopes of Maryaposs family, he said: Itaposs clear to say the family had been contacted by the production company and by the owners of the café. The family were hugely supportive of the work of the production company and I completely understand and accept that the decision made back in  by the then SIO John Bennet and then subsequently the decision that was made the previous chief constable - were reasonable decisions.  The dference here is that new information had come to light that we felt was appropriate to assess. Quite rightly we were approached, new information was provided, that new information predominantly was that there was a blue material in a void within the ground underneath the café. And under careful assessment with our team of investigators and detectives and also nationally accredited experts - we brought those in to assess that information and make a determination as to whether or not there could be a body within that cellar. I believe that the proportionate way that we went about that did take account of whether or not we should search in all areas or some areas. And the guidance and advice from those experts identied the areas that we should be spending more time searching and excavating. Itaposs unfortunate that the initial work that was done through the endoscope and the drilling by the production company couldnapost guarantee that there were no human remains or nothing connected to Maryaposs disappearance. We felt a proportionate excavation was the right, appropriate and proper thing to do. Itaposs absolutely clear that our aim here was to support the family to do everything we possibly could to put Mary to rest on their behalf and I believe that was the right decision. ACC Holden added: Everybody working on this is disappointed that we didnapost find Mary - allowing her family finally to lay her to rest after over  years is absolutely the most important reason for this investigation. Our thoughts are with Maryaposs family, whose continued dignity in recent weeks, and over the many years before, has been absolutely humbling.  Iaposm now confident that Mary is not buried in the cellar of the café, and I hope that eliminating this location will bring some small comfort to her family. We have always been clear that we might not find Maryaposs remains. Sadly, that proved to be the case on this occasion. But it does not mean that we were wrong to look - the new information made it the right thing to do. Serial killer Fred, , committed suicide in prison in  while awaiting trial for  murders. title: how getting back board improved
story: AdvertorialHow getting back on board improved one mans mental healthA National Lottery-supported group helped Marc Lawler get back on his skateboard - and it’s brought his family togethermirrorShareByLaura Tait:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY AdvertorialMarc with his son Brandon at the Hook Skate Park in NottinghamStanding at the top of the ramp, Marc Lawler felt the adrenaline begin to kick in. It was  years since he had last ridden a skateboard – he’d given it up to concentrate on his job as a welder and being a dad to his first child, Jack. But passing a skateboard shop in his hometown of Nottingham, he’d felt the pull of his old hobby. Minutes later, he walked out with a brand new board under his arm. STARTING SLOWLY That was two years ago, and Marc, now , has been brushing up on his skills. “It took me a while to get back into it, but I gradually got there,” he says. “I live opposite a skate park so I could see when it was quiet and I’d time my visits for then. Marc wasn’t sure how his body would stand up to the thrills – and inevitable spills – of the sport: “I started slowly so I didn’t hurt myself, and didn’t attempt anything more complicated than just moving round on the board at first. “I wasn’t too worried about what people thought, though. One of the good things about being older is that you care less about what people think.” As he grew more confident, Marc began to share his hobby with his family.  His -year-old son, Brandon, also had a skateboard, so the pair headed to a Skate Nottingham event, where the coaches taught them tricks and techniques. “Brandon will try stunts that I’m just too cautious to do,” says Marc. “I used to skate ramps, jumping from one and landing on another but it’s too dangerous now. I might crack my head or injure my knee and I’m too old for that. My worst injury has been a rolled ankle.” Marc sticks to street-style skating, where he uses kerbs and rails to skate on. “I taught myself to skate on rails by starting on low walls and then building up,” he explains. “It can take me anything from a week to nearly a year to learn a new trick. It feels great when I can master one that I’ve been working on for ages.” While Marc can skate some impressive rails, he’s still trying to master a basic kick flip, which involves jumping up, flipping the board over and landing on it. Skate Nottingham puts on National Lottery-funded events at skate parks, workshop venues and public spaces around the city, encouraging people of all ages to give it a go. It’s just one of many good causes to have benefited from National Lottery funding, thanks to the £ million raised every week* by players. For Marc it has become a family affair as his stepson, Bill, , joined in and the trio began to explore Nottingham’s skate parks. “We decided to visit as many as possible,” says Marc. “There are such a lot of them now and they’re all really well designed. We started before lockdown but have begun to explore dferent skate parks again now that things are beginning to open up again. And thanks to the support of The National Lottery, many of these parks have the funds to be maintained and improved. Marc started to go to more Skate Nottingham events to show others that you could skateboard regardless of your age. He also began to make friends as he saw the same faces at dferent events. “I didn’t have lots of confidence and I thought I was quite shut off from other people,” says Marc. “But it’s such an inclusive pastime that I began to really feel part of the community.” Meanwhile Marc and the boys began to record the skate parks they visited, and they have ventured further afield. At the last count they had visited around  parks, going as far as Cornwall. “We’re hoping to hit the  mark but we won’t stop there,” says Marc. “It’s become a real family affair too. My elder son, Jack, has started coming along for the ride and to explore new areas, and my -year-old stepdaughter Esme wants to get some roller skates.”  FURTHER BENEFITS As well as bringing them closer as a family, there have been some other benefits too. “It really helped with my mental health over lockdown,” says Marc. “It gave me the space to take some time for myself and unwind. And it’s helped me get to know Bill better. “I’ve also noticed that Brandon is really changing the way he approaches learning new things. In the skate park, he has to stop and assess things logically and I can see that having a positive effect at school too.” How the money you raise is raising smiles In these challenging times it’s great to be able to put a smile on people’s faces. And when you play The National Lottery you’re helping people to do exactly that – whether it’s by bringing the world of the Vikings to le or driving the unique underground train in London’s Postal Museum.  Many of those who have benefited from funding have faced their own le challenges. They include Ekow Otoo, who hasn’t let multiple sclerosis stop him achieving sporting glory. He now stars in The National Lottery’s stunning new TV ad, in which he pulls off some spectacular moves in his wheelchair at a skate park. Kate proved true to her word and when she invited little Mila Sneddon and her family to the Queen’s official Edinburgh home, wore an ME+EM outfit that matched the four-year-old’s dress. The outgoing little girl who is battling cancer has captured the duchess’ heart and when they met she told the youngster she wanted to give her a “big squeezy cuddle”. Mila was featured in an iconic picture from Kate’s lockdown photographic project and came to symbolise isolation during the pandemic after she was pictured kissing her home’s kitchen window as her father stood outside.  The little girl is undergoing chemotherapy for leukaemia and was photographed separated from her father during the first lockdown, after he had to go to work and could not risk bringing coronavirus into the family home in Falkirk.Kate and Mila had talked on the phone after the image was among  selected for the duchess’ Hold Still exhibition and book and agreed to meet up. The pair met at the Palace of Holyroodhouse and when Kate walked into the room the little girl the face of the little girl, who was joined by her parents, lit up.  “Hi Mila, look at you, Kate said. I want to give you a big squeezy cuddle, it’s so nice to meet you in person. The four-year-old stood up as did her father and mother Scott and Lynda Sneddon and her big sister Jodi. Kate praised the little girl who was dressed head-to-toe in pink with matching headband, dress and shoes. She said: “I love your dress, can you do a little twirl - and your shoes.”  The four-year-old spun round for the future Queen before running over to her father. The couple are carrying out an extensive tour of Scotland in William’s role as Lord High Commissioner to the General Assembly of the Church of Scotland.  During their visit to the Balfour Hospital in Kirkwall, William praised trauma nurse Dr Tariro Gandiya: “It must be reassuring to know we are all in this together.” The Cambridges are known by their Scottish title the Earl and Countess of Strathearn when north of the border, and Kate wore a Strathearn tartan scarf and a coat by Massimo Dutti for the visit.FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnKate Middleton, Duchess of CambridgeRoyal Family
