title: agenda-not-late-build-world-class-stem-education-system
story: A REVIEW of Scotlandrsquos Curriculum for Excellencendash the cornerstone of Scottish education ndashwill be published in June, and should be regarded as a matter of great signicance to the teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics ndash Stem for short.Calls for an independent evaluation of CfE have been years in the making, and the recommendations from the review being carried out by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development , will undoubtedly be pored over by policymakers.The Learned Societiesrsquo Group on Scottish Stem Educationsubmitted oral evidence to the OECDrsquos review, drawing together key issues in need of further national action. As we await OECDrsquos final word on the curriculum, we take this opportunity to highlight some of our concerns.CfE began as a promising development, and it is still laudable for its forward-thinking and holistic aims. Itrsquos not too late for these ambitions to be realised and used to build a world-class Stem education system, however we must first recognise the wider context that has hindered its delivery. Even the best-designed Stem curriculum will falter in the face of pervasive and persistent structural challenges.Reforming the senior phase led to a narrowing of subject choice, sowing the initial seeds for a review of CfE and contributing to declines in enrolment in Stem subjects at SCQF levels  and  since .Secondly, Scotland faces shortages of subject-specialist teachers, and secondary school laboratory technicians, both of which are critical to delivering the kind of engrossing Stem experiences which inspire lelong interest in these subjects.More widely, classrooms are having to resort to multi-course teaching ndash the dficult practice of teaching more than one course in the same timeslot ndash to combat the effects of limited staff capacity and timetabling pressures.Finally, primary teachers can lack confidence in teaching Stem an increased focus on Stem subjects in primary teacher education, both initial and career-long, is required to build teachersrsquo knowledge and understanding in these subjects.Among its widespread havoc, Covid- upended many of our traditional approaches to education, from empty classrooms to exam cancellations. Many of these adjustments were profoundly stressful and often had the greatest impact on the most disadvantaged learners. However, they also prompted important questions and challenged longstanding assumptions of what it means to assess learning.As the pandemic and its aftershocks subside, some of these changes may persist and gain further traction. There could be an opportunity to reconfigure assessments to improve their effectiveness and reduce teacher workloads. However, rather than rushing into any large-scale educational upheavals on the back of post-Covid recovery, any lessons learned will need to be sensitively applied, ensuring they bring genuine benefit for teachers, parents, and pupils alike.Stem education in Scotland faces several obstacles. While valuable in its own right, its role in building the next generation of problem-solvers and keeping Scotlandrsquos economy and research sectors internationally competitive cannot be denied. With the right systemic changes, Curriculum for Excellence can live up to its name ndash and support an exceptional Stem education system in the process.Professor David Cole-Hamilton FRSE is a Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh, and interim chair of the LSG.

title: agenda-smooth-return-work-depends-handling-change
story: HYBRID working, where people split time between home and office, is the consequence of a year of novel change in the workplace and looks set to stay. But even as businesses contemplate reopening they must remember that change is unsettling and ato "normal" may feel anything but to employees.Throughout lockdown, we carried out surveys to gauge how clients saw their businesses changing as restrictions tightened. And now, as they ease, many businesses acknowledge that office le will undergo signicant change.Accommodating flexible working means some fundamental aspects might be lost and others added. Hygiene stations and "Zoom spaces" are set to become part of office design, but the days of personal desks for every employee are numbered. And while this is a logical approach to flexible working, the wise business will bring their employees with them on the change journey, before implementing it.Physical space has to support, and be aligned with, new working practices, rather than the other way round. Whether existing space is reconfigured or new offices acquired, it is vital to engage with employees on how best to use the new space to reduce old working practices or workarounds creeping back in.We love our own desks, but our experience is that inidual desk "ownership" leads to a lot of empty desks. The loss of a space to call your own can be unsettling for iniduals, no matter how logical it might be for the business as a whole. Thought and consultation is needed to make "hot-desking" accepted. Some solutions might include personal storage or locker spaces, appropriate portable technology and providing smaller, more flexible private spaces where telephone calls or remote meetings can take place without disruption.Numerous figures have been reported with regards to future space requirementand some organisations have declared the end of the office altogether, stating that their people can work from home indefinitely. Time will tell what the actual change will be.One thing cannot be denied. People want to get back to their offices primarily to interact once more with their colleagues. The informal knowledge-sharing that comes from everyone sharing a workspace cannot be replicated through remote links alone. The sense of belonging that comes from feeling part of something bigger, and an understanding of a business culture and ethos relies on observation and interaction. This is especially true for new starts and junior staff.Physical workspace changes, which might be cost-saving can have other costs in terms of workplace happiness and productivity. So as workplaces open, the transition will ultimately be so much better for those companies that make spatial design decisions that support how their employees want to work, bring staff into the change process and not impose it upon them.Phil Muir is Group Director Consultancy and Design, SPACE

title: kevin-mckenna-cummings-statements-reveal-covid-19-response-shambolic
story: THE question by Rebecca Long-Bailey in todayrsquos evidence session of the Health and Social Care Committee cut to the heart of the UKrsquos shambolic response to Coronavirus.The Labour MP asked Dominic Cummings about his tweet last week that pointed to ldquodestructive behaviour in the political system. Cummingsrsquo response was startling.ldquoThere are brilliant people throughout the civil service but the system tends to weed them out of senior management jobs. The problem in this crisis was very much lions led by donkeys over and over again. He added: ldquoWhat is it about Whitehall that promotes so many senior people who are completely out of their depth :Cummings paints surreal picture of goings-on at dysal Number  ndash Westminster sketchCummingsrsquo recollections about the Governmentrsquos response in the critical early days of the pandemic made you think of a chimpanzeesrsquo tea-party ndash only with less mess.The head of the UK Civil Service suggested we hold ldquochickenpox parties as a means of achieving herd immunity. Yes, really. To read the rest of this analysis, sign up to The Heralds new political newsletter, Unspun, and get unrivalled political analysisevery day at pm. here.

title: mark-smith-cant-scottish-men-admit-kilt-really
story: As for how a traditional kilt is actually made, I saw the process for myself when I visited Kinloch Anderson in Leith. The kilt is made from one eight-yard stretch of material and the skill is chalking it so you know exactly where to put the pleats. The whole thing takes a skilled person about eight hours at least.The problem ndash and itrsquos the same with sporrans ndash is there are lots of cheap imports around, which has put the traditional craft under pressure. Kilt making by hand has now been added to the endangered list kept by the Heritage Crafts Association along with the likes of arrowsmithing, flintknapping, and lorinery. What it means is these wonderful traditions could disappear altogether.:Cummings paints surreal picture of goings-on at dysal Number  ndash Westminster sketchIn some ways though, it does seem strange that the threat to traditional kilt-making should come up now. The kilt has never been so ubiquitous, but maybe a lot of men think the lighter, cheaper kilt is easier to wear and lug about. The cost of a hand-made kilt can also be daunting ndash these days, you can easily pay more than pound,.The other problem with kilts is that,you do get one, it comes with a lot of baggage and attitude, some of which is a load of rubbish. For many, the kilt is the standardised vision of Scotland, but they werenrsquot always so common. My parents married in the s and it didnrsquot even cross my fatherrsquos mind to wear a kilt. I also spoke to the historian Patrick Watt about tartan and his experience was similar. Dr Watt, who was curator of modern history at the National Museum of Scotland, told me his dad did wear a kilt at his wedding in  but people asked what he was doing. ldquoLots of people wear kilts now, he said, ldquobut itrsquos a recent thing ndash in the last  years.No doubt, some of this recent enthusiasm for kilts has something to do with the recent enthusiasm for independence, the idea being that kilts are a link to national identity, rebellion or a form of modern-day Jacobitism. But all Irsquod say to that is: check your history. It may not be true, as some people think, that Highland dress was invented by Walter Scott, but the modern romantic image was popularised and spread by Queen Victoria. And check out this fact: at Culloden, there were kilted solders on both sides.Read more:Rosemary Goring: Battle royal looms as William and Kate deployed to bolster the UnionThe idea of clan tartans, which is also associated with kilts, is a modern obsession too, and an irritating one. Traditionally, people mixed and matched tartans, but now therersquos an idea that you should wear your clan tartan and,you donrsquot, a bumptious bore will tell you why you should. But why does the kilt have to be associated with ldquorules and cultural snobbery  Better to do your own thing .Finally, therersquos one other thing we should talk about, and itrsquos an issue most men are reluctant to discuss: sex and gender. I was at a ceilidh a while ago and the subject of men dressing ldquoas women came up, with most of the guys saying they were uncomfortable with the idea. I pointed out they were expressing this opinion while wearing skirts, to which their response was ldquothese arenrsquot skirts, these are kilts!That says it all, doesnrsquot it  We live in a society that says certain clothes are for women and certain clothes are for men many men also believe skirts are ldquowrong and kilts are ldquoright. But how many men are hiding their true feelings  How many men would like to try ldquowomenrsquos clothes  And how many of them are secretly doing it when they put on their kilts Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: letters-lockdown-delay-blame-lies-london-not-edinburgh
story: First, is he unaware that until the end of March  the devolved governments did not have the powers to declare a lockdown  The lockdown in Scotland on March  may have been too late, but the powers to do so lay at Westminster at that time.Secondly, I can scarcely believe that Mr Macwhirter is unaware that a lockdown without furlough ndash or some other method of maintaining incomes ndash is impossible without the economy going into meltdown, as well as widespread social disorder. Once again, the powers lay at Westminster.We know that the First Ministerrsquos adviser, Professor Devi Sridhar, recommended lockdown in February, but the First Minister, as set out above, was simply unable to follow this advice as she lacked the necessary powers.As for community testing, is Mr Macwhirter aware the testing capacity in the UK ndash the whole UK ndash on March  last year was , testsper day  How far was this going to go  Once again, this is managed by Westminster.As for protecting care homes, just last month, the BBCrsquos Head of Statistics, Robert Cuffe, said those care homes that received discharges actually had a lower rate of Covid. Moreover, charitable care home owner MHA found in a survey of its own homes as early as June last year, that ldquo% of its staff members who recently tested positive were not displaying symptoms. Nearly % of residents who had a positive test were also asymptomatic. The charityrsquos chief executive said at the time: ldquoI think itrsquos very dficult not to see that the only real way that this can have come into our homes is through staff picking it up, just through the community contacts. What seems common sense is that larger homes faced a larger problem due to a larger number of staff picking up the virus through normal community interactions.Mr Macwhirter bemoans that ldquonationalist supporters have tried to write this out of history, but they cannot. Oh yes, we will. The truth, the whole truth, is always liberating.Alasdair Galloway, Dumbarton.MSPs DETACHED FROM THE REAL WORLDTHE news that disgraced former Finance Secretary Derek Mackay will receive around pound, of taxpayers cash as a "resettlement grant" and "for losing ministerial office" along with departing MSPs who will receive grants of up to pound,shows me two things ndash first, why MSPs are so desperate to climb aboard the Holyrood gravy train and secondly, why they seem so insulated and detached from Scotlands real-world problems.Meanwhile I am trying, by robbing Peter to pay Paul, to find a way to keep my businesswhich is still closed under level  restrictions afloat. The well-paid MSPs and ministers who are still receiving their handsome salaries have very kindly decided that a grant of pound per week will help me to pay my fixed costs, pay my  per cent contribution to staff furlough costs and pay suppliers for stock purchased for the " start" date of May .If ever confirmation was needed of the agenda Nicola Sturgeon and her Cabinet have against the licensed trade this insulting figure surely provides it.Billy Gold, Hielan Jessie bar, Glasgow.UK HOLDING BACK ENERGY PROGRESSWHILE it is good to read about the Leith renewables hub and the jobs that it will bring , it seems to me that the wind turbine parts will come in by sea, probably from Denmark, then once assembled theyll be lted on to an installation vessel for transfer to an offshore site.Scotland is ideally placed to be leading the way on green energy but we are being held back by the policies of the UK Government that has not only announced cuts of support for renewables but also our electricity consumers, and green energy companies are levied the highest grid transmission charges in Europe.The Renewable UK report Charging the Wrong Way shows that billions of pounds of green infrastructure investment are being jeopardised by GB regulations which favour EU energy imports and discriminate against Scotland compared to other parts of the UK.Energy policy is reserved to Westminster and Ofgem charges Scottish Highlands and Islands pound. per Mwh to connect to the National Grid and pound. in lowland Scotland. The figure in England is p per MWh and the transmission charges for other western European countries range from zero in most countries up to pound. in Norway.Norway and Denmark have invested in state-owned hydrogen and wind power companies that are actually manufacturing the green energy products of the future while Scotland canrsquot fully capitalise on our renewable potential as part of the UK.Fraser Grant, Edinburgh.EASE UP ON THE ANTI-TORY BILEDR Angus MacMillancritiques Boris Johnson as a "con", lacking trust and unworthy of presiding over COP. Why not go the full Monty and insist that he is an Eton-educated promiscuous cad  Nothing is offered in support of his contention that Nicola Sturgeon would be better placed to champion ecological values.Complaining about diatribes delivered against Ms Sturgeon is rich. The language of political exchange adopted by the SNP is all too frequently abusive, with a particular animus directed against Mr Johnson. Day after relentless day disparaging ad hominem abusive attacks are delivered against him. Ian Blackford deploys ridicule in his verbose assaults. The SNPrsquos electronic bard Pete Wishart is similarly engaged in the juvenile pursuit of Mr Johnson with his repeated jibe that he is "a clown in clownrsquos shoes".Comparisons of Mr Johnson with Churchill are all too frequently overblown but one common characteristic is a shared determination to employ robust argument without denigrating their opponents. Both remainedadmirably resilient in the face of seemingly endless and tedious personal invective.Would it be facile to argue at this time of post-Covid reconstruction that a moderation of political invective is a necessary and sufficient condition for engendering that cooperation which all parties have declared is essential for economic and psychological recovery Cleansing of the ecological environment could benefit from an accompanying cleansing of the personalised language all too frequently in evidence in the current political environment. A good start would be an encouragement of restraint by the SNP leadership of the ritualised anti-Tory dogma espoused by its rank and file. Douglas Pitt, Newton Mearns.LETS HAVE TRUTH ON ECONOMIC PLANSTHE many unsupported assumptions and provocative questions from Isobel Lindsayavoid the realities of the constitutional situation. Have the nationalists yet come up with the solutions to the financial and trade problems of secession from the UK Pre-Covid, Scotlandrsquos annual fiscal deficit was pound billion and the annual trade deficit averaged around poundbn. To address these dire economic figures drastic austerity measures would have to be taken by an independent Scottish government ndash income tax and VAT increases, cuts to public services, sale of public assets and restrictions on imported goods. The nationalists must tell us the truth about their economic strategy,they have one.James Quinn, Lanark.HYPOCRISY OVER BURQA COMMENTSSO Boris Johnsonrsquos very nuanced article in , critical of liberal Denmark for banning the burqa, suggested that ldquoTories are insensitive to Muslim communities ndash because two words have been highlighted and over-publicised out of context .But Remona Aly, the liberal female Muslim journalist who does not wear a full veil, was able to quote sardonically and humorously, both the "letterbox and ldquobank robber descriptions of headgear worn by some Muslim women, in herarticle on November , . She received no criticism or backlash whatsoever.The PMrsquos critics must also know that Labourrsquos former Home Secretary, Jack Straw, said he did not feel comfortable in meetings with constituents whose face he could not see, and that shadow minister Emily Thornberry said on Question Time she would not want a burqa-clad woman looking after her four-year old or her elderly mother.They should also acknowledge that it is certainly possible for bank robbers or worse, of either sex, to disguise themselves in such attire. A learner driver was convicted in July  of hiding a headset in her hijab while taking her theory test in London.John Birkett, St Andrews.Read more: Dominic Cummings saga could see Nicola Sturgeon caught in the crossfire

title: letters-great-scottish-sporting-achievement-sidelined-english-centric-news-values
story: The Prestonpans light-welterweight had gone into his unication fight against Joseacute Ramiacuterez with two of the four world titles to his name, on a par with Watford-born heavyweight Anthony Joshua, but was fighting to become the first British boxer to become holder of the quartet of titles in the "four belt era".It was curious enough that the Taylor Ramiacuterez contest was not covered live by any of the UKs main pay-per-view channels such as Sky or BT Sport ndash it was eventually streamed live on the specialist boxing  FITE TV for a one-off payment of pound ndash but the ing Scottish heros homecoming failed to make the cut on any on the main UK-wide news channels.Rather, on the day of Taylorsto the UK from Las Vegas ndash passing through London Heathrow en route to Edinburgh ndash the main news channels deployed their esteemed sports editorsto the announcement of Gareth Southgates provisional squad for the delayed Euro , Englands opening fixture still a full three weeks away, his final -man squad still a week from being finalised.Whilst appreciating the numbers game between Scotland and England and the juxtaposition in popularity between football and boxing, surely Taylors unprecedented actual achievement should have carried signicantly greater editorial weight ahead of a provisional squad pre-announcement for one team taking part in an event that will not reach its denouement for almost two months Given such England-centric prejudice in drawing-up daily national news agendas, is it little wonder that we Scots ndash and incidentally Welsh and Northern Irish too ndash feel so undervalued and alienated, when our ground-breaking national achievements are at best sidelined and all too often ignored in favour of what are, in reality, second rate ndash but English ndash stories Mike Wilson, Longniddry.YES, ISRAEL SHOULD APOLOGISEIN reply to the letter by M Green , yes, Israel should apologise. For cynical actions in East Jerusalem that deliberately sought to provoke a reaction from Hamas that would distract attention from Netanyahus dishonesty and illegality. For operating an apartheid state where Arab Israelis do not have the same rights as Jewish Israelis. For turning Gaza into a refugee camp instead of allowing an independent Palestine state to flourish.Israel will never enjoy peace while it continues to oppress Palestinians. I share the view that Hamas are extremist thugs who use civilians as a human shield, but I cant see what Israel is achieving by bombing these innocent people. The US should insist on a two-state solution as a condition of further support for Israel.Sandy Slater, Stirling.TIME TO AIR PRIVATE CONCERNSGUY Stenhouserehashes his opinion that private is good and public is bad in almost all his columns. Reading the same point made week after week, I am tempted to askyou pay him with the same cheque week after week. If not, you should certainly consider it.Irsquod like to ask Mr Stenhouse two questions:Has he ever visited the AE department of a private American hospital where his credit card would be more important than his illness Has he tried comparing the publicly-owned French railways with their privatised British equivalent  A French TGV would take him  miles in less time than a British train for less than half the price.Sam Craig, Glasgow.WHY THE FUSS ABOUT LEAVING SCHOOL ALTHOUGH I am only  years old, the letterfrom Ed Brown complaining that there would be no ldquoreal celebrations for his daughter leaving primary school confirmed once more that the modern world is something completely alien to me.When my friends and I left primary school there were no celebrations, organised or otherwise. Proms were unheard of. We just got on with it. It was no big deal and none of us were any the worse for it.David Clark, Tarbolton.AYE I MIGHT I join David Brown and David Millerin their club for Grumpy Old Men  Having squirmed when I read Nicola Loves columnand her statement that a quick call had secured "my partner and I" vaccination appointments, I concluded that the blame must lie squarely at the door of Oscar Hammerstein II for failing to correctly name his musical The King and Me.Eric Begbie, Stirling.A MUTE POINTI WAS shocked to learn that comedian Les Dennis is now involved in an opera production by Gilbert and Sullivan . I am not shocked by the radical change of direction in his career but by the description of the work of Gilbert and Sullivan as "opera".I am with the late Italian conductor Arturo Toscanini  per cent when he said that Italian opera should be sung in Italian. French opera in French, German opera in German and English opera should not be sung at all.Poor Verdi, Bizet and Wagner will all be rolling over in their graves.Tina Oakes, Stonehaven.

title: sturgeons-grand-plans-deserve-scrutiny-match
story: But then along comes one like yesterdayrsquos extraordinary appearance by Dominic Cummings, with the Prime Ministerrsquos former adviser, at times appearing agonised by the deadly chaos he saw and helped get elected, sledgehammering his old boss and a dismal Whitehall machine.It was an unprecedented occasion. A key witness eager to unburden himself and point the finger on an issue with the highest possible stakes. We will not see its like again for some time, I bet.Parliamentary committees, whether examining government departments or poring over legislation, are rarely so compelling. Especially at Holyrood.One of the interesting dferences between yesterdayrsquos session and the typical Scottish Parliament offering was who was in charge.:Cummings paints surreal picture of goings-on at dysal Number  ndash Westminster sketchOpening the questions and setting the tone of blunt inquiry was Greg Clark, a minister from the outset of the Toriesto power in , who held two cabinet posts and is now chair of the Commons science and technology select committee.The other lead inquisitor was Jeremy Hunt, a three-time cabinet secretary from  to  who now chairs the health and social care committee.It is not unusual for former big beasts to chair select committees, posts that are not only elected by MPs, conferring authority, but are remunerated at pound, a year, so the occupants have to earn their keep.It helps maintain the tradition of independent-minded scrutiny, even by MPs of the governing party.The experience former ministers bring to the job is also invaluable as they know best how the system works and how best to penetrate the wiles and evasions of officialdom.Both Mr Clark and Mr Hunt are Tories perfectly willing to make le hard for a Tory Prime Minister.Yes, both were Remainers ousted in Boris Johnsonrsquos first reshuffle, so there may be personal factors at play, but they are still part of a healthier-than-Holyrood system where loyalty to onersquos party is not paramount.Meanwhile in Edinburgh, it is rare for recent ministers to be committee conveners, and rarer still for former cabinet secretaries to take on the role.In the - Scottish parliament, there were only three former SNP ministers who led committees, and only two in the - session, when one former cabinet secretary also fleetingly took charge of a committee for two recess months one year.In Westminster, committee chair is a perfectly respectable afterle for a former minister or cabinet secretary, with remuneration offering lsquojam todayrsquo to make up for the workload.Holyrood is quite dferent. Conveners are not elected by the parliament as a whole, but by the MSPs on each committee.:Battle royal looms as William and Kate deployed to bolster the UnionWith parties choosing which MSPs go where, it gives the government of the day a huge say in who gets many of the gigs, and naturally it has no wish to implant thorns in its own side.Convenerships are very often the stepping stones to ministerial office.There is no remuneration for the considerable amount of extra graft.Instead, there is the lure of lsquojam tomorrowrsquo in the form of promotion.That incentivises loyalty to the government and not causing a fuss.Other MSPs of the governing party follow this example. Mavericks, such as Alex Neil, are welcome but rare.Holyroodrsquos committee system was famously supposed to be the jewel in its crown, offering the scrutiny of a second chamber without the cost.But as we enter a sixth parliamentary term, its clear theyrsquove been a let-down, arguably reaching their nadir in the gutless toadying from some SNP MSPs during the Alex Salmond inquiry.Some problems come down to the parliamentrsquos size. The talent pool is more paddling than ing.Even with the SNP having close to a majority, around a fth of all MSPs are part of the government, and so unavailable for committee duty.Infrequent reshuffles mean a low turnover in ministers, so government experience is lacking among the rest.The present First Ministerrsquos habit of re-hiring old hands also leaves former ministers who are on committees wonderingthey might one day , so best to bite their tongue.There have been many tinkering attempts at reform. In , then Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick asked the Standards Committee to investigate the case for elected conveners, an idea she supported.ldquoIf conveners were elected by the whole Parliament, they would derive their authority and mandate from the Parliament itself, she said.ldquoThis sht of responsibility... would strengthen the role of the Parliament and so enhance the sharing of power between the government, the Parliament and the people.The Committee preferred fudge, concluding the Parliament ldquoshould set aside the idea on elected conveners and discuss general scrutiny instead.The next PO, Ken Macintosh, tried again, establishing an independent commission on parliamentary reform to help improve scrutiny.It backed elected conveners, with procedures in place from the start of the current session, with potential remuneration based on workload.The committees have yet to be formed for this session, but there is no sign yet of any elections or pay bumps.Instead, it looks like the same old patronage and pusillanimity.Nicola Sturgeon yesterday promised ldquounashamedly ambitious policies for the coming term, while priding herself on Holyrood not transplanting ldquothe old ways of Westminster.But grand plans merit deep scrutiny and Holyrood doesnrsquot offer it.ldquoWe do not claim a monopoly of wisdom, the First Minister added.In that case,some Westminster ways are worth importing, do it.

title: glasgow-road-closures-announced-cop26-summit
story: Details of roads close to the event at the citys SEC campus have been released for the first time along with a map.It comes as businesses are being invited to sign-up for an event to find out about the work being done to prepare Glasgow for the arrival COP.The virtual event is being organised as part of the Get Ready Glasgow campaign developed by Glasgow City Council in partnership with event organisers - the UK Government, and with Police Scotland and Glasgow Chamber of Commerce.Read more:Scotlands covid memorial campaign boosted by trust fund donationAs host city of this potentially historic climate change summit, Glasgow is in a position to raise its profile globally as a sustainable city, attract investment to key sectors and promote itself as a visitor destination.Get Ready Glasgow campaign is aimed at keeping the city moving and open for business in the lead up to and during the COP conference.It will also be used to make sure the city is prepared to welcome visitors and that citizens feel confident and reassured about Glasgow hosting a covid-safe event.The event comes as details of the impact of the conference on this cityrsquos road network around the main venue, the SEC, and river restrictions are announced. These measures are needed to facilitate the safe delivery of the event and maintain the safety and security of participants, citizens and visitors:Exact dates on the period of road closures and when they will come into effect are still to be confirmed but will be widely communicated in the coming months.Glasgow road closures in place for COPDiversion routes will be in place around the SEC to keep traffic moving and, as with previous city events, Local Area Traffic Management Plansare being developed to keep traffic moving for road users.Active travel routes are still being refined, however, pedestrian and cycle access will be maintained on Finnieston Street, Lancefield Quay and Clyde Arc at all times as will routes for emergency services.The River Clyde will be closed to private and commercial vessels ahead of and during COP. It is proposed that a safety zone is established from the first tidal weir at Glasgow Green to a position just east of King George V Docks. This stretch of the river will not be able to host vessels or water-based activities around the summit site.To keep the city moving and open for business, people will be advised to prepare journeys in advance, but with built in flexibility in case of unexpected disruption.The campaign also includes further engagement sessions in the lead up to COP and the development of a business ready guide, due to be published late June.The Get Ready Glasgow website will also provide information about plans to deliver a covid-safe event based on the most up-to-date public health guidance, and what measures will be put in place to protect citizens and the participants in COP.Ros Eales, Chief Operating Officer, COP Unit said: ldquoCOP, is an exciting and historic moment for the city. The Conference will be an inclusive event, bringing together world leaders, delegates, academics, businesses, civil society groups and activists from over the world to inspire climate change action.ldquoSupport from businesses in the city and the people of Glasgow is crucial to making this Conference a success and we thank you, as well as other businesses and communities of Glasgow, for your support so far and look forward to continuing to work with you this year.Councillor Susan Aitken, Leader of Glasgow City Council, said: ldquoThe purpose of Get Ready Glasgow is to ensure that business and residents have the information they need to go about their daily lives while COP is running.ldquoPlanning teams concentrating on city operations have been established to manage the impact of COP on the city and what impact the events will have on the services that the council provides to businesses and residents in their day-to-day lives.ldquoIf we start to talk about some of the things that may change in the lead up to and during the COP now, people, particularly businesses, can begin to think about how they may need to adapt their operations, particularly on the days where the city may be busier than usual, due to the main COP programme or side events.ldquoCOP will change the way the city runs for a period of time in November but we will make sure that everyone is well informed and when the time comes people can feel proud at Glasgow having played its part in the success of such a globally signicant event.Routes around the SEC campus will be affected during COPAssistant Chief Constable Bernard Higgins, Police Scotland, said COP will be one of the most high profile and signicant security and policing events ever held in the United Kingdom.He said: ldquoCOP presents some unique policing challenges but Police Scotland is well prepared for any eventuality. Our main focus will be on the delivery of a safe and secure event and also managing likely activist activity, while keeping the city, and indeed the country, operational and moving.Stuart Patrick, Chief Executive of the Glasgow Chamber of Commerce, said few events in Glasgowrsquos history can match the signicance of the cityrsquos hosting of COP.Mr Patrick said: "It is an opportunityto show just how much our city can contribute both to solving climate change andtolaying the foundations for our next phase of economic growth.There will be a signicant and positive long-term impact ofGlasgow being at the centre of the solutions.ldquoIt is vitally important that plans are made and implemented to handle the event and its impact on the day-to-day running of the city, and Glasgow Chamber is ready and willing to support these plans in our role as the mechanism to engage with the business community.

title: time-scottish-businesses-get-handle-green-revolution-climate-solutions
story: THE climate emergency is all around us. It now influences our thoughts and actions in innumerable ways, so it is essential that we are properly informed about it. The more we understand, the more we can do to combat it.Learning is the key to this, and itrsquos an area in which Scotland is emerging as a global leader. Today, The Herald is launching an exciting and empowering new programme that aims to bring climate change discussion and solutions to iniduals and organisations everywhere ndash not just in this country, but around the world.Our Herald Climate Solutions initiative is linked with Climate Solutions Network, a pioneering new initiative developed by The Royal Scottish Geographical Society in association with the Institute of Directors , Universities of Stirling and Edinburgh and Jump Digital.This ground-breaking project offers two compelling courses allowing participants to learn about the climate crisis and how they can help to address it.One is the Climate Solutions Professional., which consists of four easy-to-follow web-based modules and an online workshop. It will help time-poor managers to understand climate issues and their relevance to their organisations and personal lives.The second is Climate Solutions Accelerator, an express online learning programme which teaches the basics in vital areas such as climate science and policy legislation and offers ideas around solutions in just  minutes.Both courses feature highly motivational materials as well as contributions from some of the worldrsquos leading figures in the fight against climate change.Those featured include global campaigner Greta Thunberg, former Bank of England Governor Mark Carney, ex-Irish President Mary Robinson, former Norwegian Premier Gro Harlem Brundtland and recent UN Secretary General Ban Ki-moon.The programmes are the brainchild of Mike Robinson, CEO of the Perth-based Royal Scottish Geographical Society and a veteran climate change and sustainability campaigner.In  he helped found, and chaired, Stop Climate Chaos Scotland, the largest civil society coalition ever formed in this country.What drove him to launch this new programme  ldquoIt became obvious to me that far too many people still didnrsquot understand the relevance of climate change to their businesses and they didnrsquot have the time to sort that out, he explains. ldquoI realised I had built up a lot of knowledge in this area and that there wasnrsquot anything out there that could teach people what they could do. So I got together with the IoD and Edinburgh and Stirling Universities to produce this course.The full four-module course has recently been launched and contains some  hours of online learning as well as the two workshops. ldquoThere is a lot of expertise crammed into it. We had already had about  people subscribe to it, including  in the Scottish Government.ldquoItrsquos aimed at people who are managers, directors or board members ndash anyone who wants to have a robust organisation. Wersquove got people signed up from a whole range of sectors and I think that is part of its appeal. The point is that climate change is now pervasive. It goes beyond the Sustainability Officer or a single department.ldquoItrsquos going to impact every aspect of organisations, so itrsquos really important that everyone from the board through to Finance Directors through to those in personnel, HR, purchasing and other areas has a better and more rounded understanding of where this is all going.ldquoWe do touch on the science, though that has been settled for quite a long time and we only tell people what they really need to know. Then therersquos another part that is about the inevitability of the direction of travel.ldquoPeople need to realise the ways things are going on this ndash the forthcoming COP conference in Glasgow later this year is a case in point. International commitments on climate change are ramping up year on year.The shorter, single session Climate Solutions Accelerator programme offers the basics in an easy-to-digest fashion. Several organisations have signed up to put their entire senior management, and in some cases their entire workforce, through one or other of the two courses. And this appeal is global.ldquoOne major US company enrolled some of its Scottish staff in an early session of the full course and quickly decided that the learning and knowledge gained needed to be rolled out to all its staff globally, more to follow on this. Wersquore getting a sense now that there is a really strong appetite for this sort of thing ndash businesses really want to understand the issues and get on top of them quickly.ldquoThe global names wersquove brought in on both of the programmes to help convey the message have helped with the content and to make it clear why people need to wake up to this issue.Although the courses are attracting interest worldwide,Mike Robinson says that they are unapologetically Scottish. ldquoCountries are at dferent points and therersquos no question that Scotland is well ahead of the rest of the world on this journey.ldquoNo-one is perfect in this, but the UK is the leading country on addressing climate issues in the G and Scotland is the leader within the UK, with much more stringent commitments than the other parts. That means that we have a responsibility, but there is also an opportunity for us in terms of leadership. Itrsquos about helping people understand the whole of the debate so they can be better informed and better prepared. I hope that by taking the courses, they will be better able to build change and deliver the future.

title: lorna-slater-scottish-greens-optimistic-formal-agreement-snp-holyrood
story: Ms Slater said that she "wouldnt expect" any deal between the parties to mirror the format set down by alliances between the Liberal Democrats with both Labour and the Conservatives at Holyrood and Westminster in recent years.The newly-elected MSP said that talks with Nicola Sturgeons SNP were in a very early stage and may not be resolved for months, and that both parties were looking for common ground.:Nicola Sturgeon in talks with Greens over groundbreaking cooperation dealThe First Minister announced yesterday thather SNP Government is holding talks with the Scottish Greens over a possible "formal cooperation agreement".The First Minister said the move could see Green MSPs entering the Scottish Government as ministers.Structured talks, supported by the civil service, will now take place with a view to reaching a deal between the SNP and the Greens.Ms Slater is no-leader with Patrick HarvieSpeaking this morning, Ms Slater said that the aim was to establish a "new kind of politics".She told BBC Radio Scotland: "What were hoping to achive is to create a dferent kind of working environment in the Scottish Parliament to prioritize the kind of things that really matter to the Scottish Green Party - which is a fair and green recovery from the pandemic."To put practical actions in place to tackle the climate crisis. Were theparty that has the policies that are needed to tackle the climate crisis and of course were pleased the government has recognised that and reached out to say right, lets work on this together."Lets take a serious stand on this and take some serious action."Ms Slater did not rule out Green MSPs taking ministerial roles, saying that systems used in other countries could provide a blueprint.:Lorna Slater says Scottish Greens will have more influence than everShe said: "The New Zealand Greens, for example, have a co-operation arrangement where they hold ministerial positions but are not part of cabinet."The co-operation agreement means that those Green ministers take responsibility for very specic areas. I think its climate change and housing."Ms Slater added: "Were very excited about going into these formal talks. The climate crisis is the number one crisis that were all dealing with, and its very exciting that we do have a new kind of politics on the table."She continued:"We are at the absolute start of the process. The Scottish government and he Scottish Greens are going in with optimisma spirit of co-operation and a genuine desire to do politics dferently."Thats where we are at the starting block right now and well all have to see where it comes to in a couple of months time."

title: whistles-close-glasgow-store-18-years-trading
story: The brand,which is a favourite of the Duchess of Cambridge,is to move out of Princess Square, ending an -year history with theBuchanan Streetshopping centre.Katie Moody, of Princes Square, said the centre was saddened by the decision.Customers were being directed to the companys Edinburgh store on George Street.Whistles announced the closure of its Nottingham store in April.The company wasfounded in  by Lucille and Richard Lewin.In January ,Jane Shepherdson, formerTopshopdirector, signed a deal to purchase a  per cent stake in the brand and was appointed the job of chief executive.She was widely credited for weathering what the label described as ldquochallenging trading conditions and ing it to profitability in .Whistles was bought by the South African retailer, Foschini Group in , which also owns Phase Eight.The company announced the closure of its Nottingham store in April.Katie Moody, of Princes Square, said:"We can confirm that after  years in Princes Square, Whistles will close their flagship Glasgow store next month."We are very sad to see them go.": Store wars: Can Edinburgh take Glasgows retail crown with new offeringsThe pandemic has led to some of the biggest high street names folding or being taken over by other brands.While supermarkets have seen a boost in profits, non-essential brands have struggled to stay afloat.Top Shop, which had two stores in Glasgow city centre, was bought over by the online retailer ASOS ending a long-standing and pivotal high street presence.Other big name brands which have closed stores in other cities include John Lewis, which has closed its Aberdeen store.Debenhams launched an % off sale ahead of shutting all of its UK stores including Glasgow.The department store chain collapsed at the end of last year, with the closure of all its stores confirmed after Boohoo agreed to only buy its website and brand in a pound million rescue deal.: Boohoo buys Debenhams brand and website for poundmillionIn March, luxury brand Hermegraves announced it was shutting its only Scottish store at House of Fraser in Glasgow.ldquoGlasgow is definitely going through a rough time, therersquos no getting away from it, says Dr Cara Connell, a lecturer in fashion and marketing at Glasgow Caledonian University.ldquoWhen you walk up and down and see the number of store closures.ldquoHowever, just recently All Saints have said they are moving to a bigger store next door on Buchanan Street because they say their Glasgow store is their biggest revenue store in the UK after Regent Street. Itrsquos not a completely grim picture.ldquoGlasgow and style and fashion is not dead but I think it more comes down to the brands themselves and the position they are in and how resilient they are and how well placed they have been to weather the storm.ldquoYou donrsquot hear ittalked about as much as it once was. Itrsquos such an iconic store, though, that one.: poundmillion plan for hospitality hub at former Debenhams storeDr Connell said the sht to online shopping during the pandemic would have hit some fashion retailers harder than others.ldquoI think a big challenge for a brand like Whistles and their target market is that itrsquos that slightly older -plus female consumer who is now shopping almost near exclusively online. Thatrsquos been one of the biggest changes in consumer behaviour. Itrsquos the younger demographics who are still keen to go in and try things.ldquoIt was a trend that was happening before but the pandemic has definitely exacerbated that.ldquoThe typical Whistles customers might have children and parents they are caring for so they are so time squeezed. We are also out of the habit of going in to meet friends for lunch in town.The Herald has contacted Whistles for comment.

story: Hearing Dominic Cummings discuss the scientic ldquogroup think about herd immunity took me back to March  and an unpleasant experienceHaving listened to the National Clinical Director, Jason Leitch explain that, in the absence of a cure, we would have to manage the spread of the disease ldquothrough the community until ldquoherd immunity was achieved, I made the mistake of trying to explain this on social media. title: uk-australia-trade-deal-likened-highland-clearances-snp-accused-isolationism
story: Kenny MacAskill challenged Greg Hands, UK trade minister, over the plans in the Commons this afternoon, saying the Tories ldquodonrsquot even care about Scottish sheep let alone crofters and farmers.The trade deal has raised concerns with farmers across the UK, who are worried that cheap imports of beef and lamb could see the demand for their home-grown produce dwindle.Others say they are worried about inferior products, such as hormone-injected beef coming to the UKs supermarkets - a claim the Government denies and says hormone-injected beef would never be allowed to be imported to the country.Mr MacAskill, Alba MP for East Lothian said: ldquoOver  years ago the Highland Clearances saw people shamefully replaced by sheep for landlord profits.ldquoNow this trade deal threatens to supplant those sheep with cheap imports for Tory dogma.Mr Hands replied that the production costs in the Asian markets were ldquotwice what they are in the UK adding: ldquo[This] makes it very competitive for Australia to sell into for example, markets like Japan, markets like Korea, where the domestic production price of beef is twice that in the UK.He added that the Australian lamb quota into the UK was ldquonot even fully used at the moment.Drew Hendry, the SNP MP for Inverness, Nairn, Badenoch and Strathspey, cited warnings from the National Farmersrsquo UnionScotland and England, saying they would struggle to competetarf-free access was granted to Australian beef and lamb exporters.Mr Hendry said the government was ldquosimply not listening to those at the sharp end and quoted NFU Scotland president Martin Kennedy, who said: ldquoOur seafood industry has already been hit hard by Brexit and now Scottish farming is next to be sacriced. Once again its Scotlands key industries which will bear the brunt of a Tory Brexit people here didnt vote for.Mr Hendry continued: ldquoNFU England warned ministers that they would struggle to compete of zero-tarfs trade on lamb or beef went ahead and the RSPCA have warned that tarf free access for Australia would betray the public, farmers, and the animals. These are just some of the warnings to government from those affected, not from politicians.ldquoWill the minister rule out tarf-free access for Australian agricultural produce However Mr Hands hit back, accusing the SNP of being ldquoisolationist and said Mr Hendry had ldquoserious questions to answer.He said: ldquoNever in  years has the SNP supported any trade deal done by either the UK, or even by the EU, even though key sectors of the Scottish economy like whiskey, like apparel, like fisheries, are dependent on trade.ldquoThey voted for no-deal Brexit, they voted against deals with our friends like Canada, Korea and South Africa. They didnt support deals with Japan or Singapore.ldquoI dont think that whatever assurances I have given you today or whatever turns out to actually be in the deal would make him and the SNP support this deal.ldquoWhen it comes to trade Mr Speaker, the SNP are isolationist and against the best interests of Scotland. ldquoPatricia Gibson, SNP MP also challenged Mr Hands, asking him why farmers could not understand ldquohow fabulous the UKrsquos deal was and adding: ldquoCould it be the case that this government is being disingenuous about the impact this deal will have on your farmers The minister said that Scotland would ldquobenefit from this deal very strongly overall.

story: Scottish Government statistics have confirmed that new cases of the virus have been identied since Wednesday, a fall of  on the day before.During that time there were no newdeaths of someone who tested positive for the disease within the past  days,meaning the death toll under this measure remains,.:Nicola Sturgeon blames Boris Johnsons bad decisions for loss of le from CovidSeparate figures from National Records ofScotland, which count the number where Covid- was mentioned on a death certicate, put the toll at , as of  May.Out of the newtests whichthat reported results, .% were positive, lower than the % the WorldHealthOrganisationbelieves indicates a pandemic is coming under control.: Matt Hancock saysScottish Government had same issues to deal with on care homesAccording to the latest statistics, the vaccination programme has now administered ,, first doses, while ,, peoplehave received a second, taking the overall total to more than five million.A total of  people remain in hospital receivingtreatmentfor the virus,down  on the previous day, while fourarein intensive care, a fall from six.Nicola Sturgeon said the reduction in hospital cases of coronavirus and another small drop in the number of patients in ICU as ldquoreasons to be optimistic.Ms Sturgeon said the Scottish Government wants to get Glasgow back on track ldquoas quickly as possible, but thatrsquos got to be done responsibly and safely.The city is the only part of Scotland still under Level  restrictions.Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoWe see a reduction in hospital cases today, and a small reduction in ICU cases, so there are reasons to be optimistic there, but wersquove got to continue ndash in the interest of business and in the interest of everybody ndash to take careful and cautious decisions to get the whole country back to normality.

title: galloway-hoard-ancient-puzzle-revealed-restored-treasures-go-show
story: And now the secrets of the Galloway Hoard are being revealed as the treasure trove of silver, gold and textiles goes on show after being painstakingly restoredfor the first time.The th-century collectionof more than  objects, including gold, silver, jewellery, a rare Anglo-Saxon cross and textiles, was found in a field in Dumfries and Galloway by a metal detectorist in  and acquired by National Museums Scotlandin .Painstaking cleaning, conservation and cutting-edge research over the past few years has revealed the stories of some of the objects, including a unique lidded vessel which is wrapped in textiles.This silver-gilt jar, which is too fragile to form part of the display, contained a secret which conservationists say will puzzle the team for years to come.:Stunning detail of silver cross revealed after painstaking restorationInstead of precious metals or valuable coins, it contained glass beads and two balls of simple earth.D models, taken from X-ray imaging, have enabled researchers to see beneath the textiles which have hidden it for more than , years, giving them a glimpse of the decorated surface of the vessel, which features leopards, tigers and a Zoroastrian fire altar.The decorations revealed that rather than being from the CarolingianEmpire as expected, the metalwork is likely from the Sassanid Empire of Central Asia, while radiocarbon dating of the wool wrapping dates it to AD -, predatingthe Viking age by up to  years.Dr Martin Goldberg, principal curator of medieval archaeology and history at NMS, said: ldquoThis is only the third silver-gilt and decorated vessel to be found as part of a Viking-age hoard in the UK, and so we might have expected it to be like the other two.ldquoHowever, the D model reveals that the vessel is not from the CarolingianEmpire of continental Europe as wersquod expected based on other similar examples. Instead, the decoration and design suggests that it is a piece of Central Asian metalwork from halfway round the known world.ldquoWhat was revealed was decoration that is unlike the other two, they were made in a Christian context in the Carolingian empire probably sometime in the th century AD.ldquoOur vessel has non-Christian symbolism on it and in particular there is a central icon which is a Zoroastrian fire altar and Zoroastrianismwas the state religion of the Sassanian empire, which is much further to the east in central Asia, what was Persia and is modern day Iran, and there are leopards and tigers in the vegetation on the vessel and the whole thing just has a much dferent symbolism.ldquoIt was quite a surprise, itrsquos really opened up that international picture.Dr Chris Breward, director of NMS, described the hoard as ldquoprobably the most signicant find from the period of the Vikings in Britain or Ireland that we know of.The exhibition, which opens on Saturday, shows how the hoard was buried in four distinct parcels ndash two of silver bullion and one a cluster of four elaborately-decorated silver ldquoribbon arm-rings bound together and concealing a small wooden box containing three items of gold.:poundm grant will help unwrap Viking hoard secretsThe final parcel was a lidded, silver gilt vessel wrapped in layers of textile and packed full of carefully wrapped objects that appear to have been curated like relics or heirlooms.They include beads, pendants, brooches, bracelets, an elaborate belt-set, a rock crystal jar and other curios, often strung or wrapped with silk, as well as two mysterious balls of dirt containing tiny specks of gold.The beads found in the containerThese balls are similar to other lumps of earth preserved by the Vatican archives, purported to have been dug up by pilgrims in the Holy Land of the Middle East and brought back to Europe.Samples of the actual ground Jesus and the apostles walked on would have been considered holy relics, explaning why they were secreted away among other more obvious valuables.It is not known why the hoard, which had items belonging to four owners, was buried, though they were typically hidden by people under threat or stress who hoped to reclaim them later.Research into the hoard, found by metal detectorist Derek McLennan, continues through a pound million project led by NMS in partnership with the University of Glasgow.The exhibition Galloway Hoard: Viking-age Treasure will be open at the National Museum of Scotland in Chambers Street, Edinburgh, until September  when it will then tour to Kirkcudbright Galleries and Aberdeen Art Gallery.

title: term-digital-native-term-not-compute-scottish-classrooms
story: TECHNOLOGY is ubiquitous: it surrounds us to the point where we use it intuitively and virtually without noticing. We ask it to do remarkable things and it complies, usually immediately and uncomplainingly.Thatrsquos both a blessing and a curse. Computers and IT are simultaneously our best friend and an inhibitor to our advancement. We know things will happen when we click an app without ever really thinking about how it works or remembering that skilled people have worked to create and polish that app.This creates an assumption and an entitlement that acts as a barrier to learning when it comes to learning computer science. If youngsters in particular grow up with technology all around them, the thinking goes, then why should they feel the need to build that technology themselves Todayrsquos children are generallyregarded as what are known as lsquodigital nativesrsquo ndash young people who have grown up with computers and the internet as an integral part of their lives and as such, they are all comfortable and confident using these things.But the challenge is getting them to realise thatthey donrsquot develop a consciousness and a curiosity about the technology in their hands, itrsquos hard to convince them that they should consider a career in the science underlying it.To put it another way,someone is having a smooth ride in a modern car, they really donrsquot need to think about what is happening underneath the bonnet in the engine compartment. Therersquos an assumption because modern vehicles are so comfortable and reliable, we really no longer need mechanics. Until, of course, the car breaks down.When applied to computer science, this assumptive ethos is of concern to educators and in particular to Digital Xtra Fund, a Scotland-wide charity working to build interest in computing and technology among those aged  and under through extracurricular activities.Kraig Brown, the Fundrsquos Partnerships and Development Manager, believes this attitude is creating problems when it comes to getting students engaged in programmes such as the ones supported by his own organisation and others such as dressCode, which works to inspire Scottish girls to learn computing.ldquoThe term lsquodigital nativersquo implies that computer users donrsquot need to take computing science. It also assumes that they will automatically have the skills they need to enter the sort of tech-centric careers we are trying to encourage students into.ldquoThat might be the case for a minority, but it certainly isnrsquot for a majority. In fact, the phrase lsquodigital nativersquo diminishes the work that we do by suggesting the programmes we support for young people arenrsquot really needed.He adds: ldquoThey can go through school thinking that all they need to do is pick up an iPad and they can find everything they need on the internet.ldquoBut when they get beyond school and into university or an apprenticeship, they find they do need some computer science skills for a lot of careers in the world today ndash and not just tech-based roles. Once they realise they donrsquot have the necessary skills to get into many job markets, what do they do then  They can reskill or upskill but itrsquos much easierwe instil these computing skills earlier.Kraig makes the point that previous generations using popular early domestic computers such as the Commodore  or BBC Micro generally had to learn something about programming.ldquoYou had to know about computational thinking just to use them! Modern computers have eliminated that need. Thatrsquos good in many ways, it makes technology more accessible, but it also means many modern users donrsquot have those skills anymore.The declining numbers of computer science teachers in Scottish schools over the last  years hasnrsquot helped the situation. Even in , computer science is not taught in every secondary school.In the Highlands alone ndash an area nearly the size of Belgium ndash there are nine full-time Computer Science teachers covering  secondary schools. ldquoI think most senior leadership teams in schools appreciate how important the subject is by now, but because many donrsquot have the staff or resources, they canrsquot be as proactive in promoting the subject or getting their students as involved as they would like.Last yearrsquos Logan Review into education produced for the Scottish Government recommended that computer science should be treated as a core subject such as maths and physics.Kraig supports this, though he concedes the shortage of computing teachers will be an issue. ldquoThe challenges with computer science at the secondary level is negatively impacting a lot of young people in Scotland, eventhey donrsquot know it yet. I believe one solution is to aggressively upskill our primary teachers and introduce computing skills at an earlier stage to give them the foundational skills they need as well as excite them about the possibilities of tech.Recruiting more computer science teachers or introducing these skills earlier wonrsquot helpthere isnrsquot uptake from young people in secondary and beyond. How can the question of exciting students about building computing skills be successfully addressed  He believes the learning must be directly connected to real le.ldquoIn my opinion, the best way is to get industry involved ndash ideally young experts or professionals, but really anyone who can talk about their career, the skills they use, and how technology impacts this. So much of what we do in daily le is based on technology and the pandemic has only amplied this. It has also highlighted the growing importance of having technology and connectivity in place for all.Many people born before  have recently learned new digital skills as a matter of necessity. Kraig believes that the same kind of urgency and thinking is now required to inspire todayrsquos generation of young people to take the next steps to become digital creators and digital leaders, not simply lsquodigital nativesrsquo.www.digitalxtrafund.scot

title: hms hood to be commemorated in orkney
story: A series of online events will mark the th anniversary of the sinking of one of the UK#s most famous naval vessels.Another Orkney Production’sannual event Celebrating Scapa Flow kicks off, this Friday evening, online. This year commemorate HMS Hood with an online programme on May  and , hosted in conjunction with the Orkney International Science Festival.Shortly before midnight on May , , HMS Hood weighed anchor and sailed out of Scapa Flow through Hoxa Sound to patrol the waters south of Iceland and prevent Germany’s largest battleship, Bismarck, from reaching the North Atlantic.On May , a battle in the Denmark Strait resulted in the loss of HMS Hood. She sank within minutes of being hit, with the loss of , lives. Only three of her ,-strong crew survived.The weekend#s events will be broadcast online on the Orkney International Science Festival Youtube channel. The programme begins this evening at pm with HMS Hood, Last of her Kind — a discussion involving Captain Christ Smith, Cdr William Sutherland Cdr David Hobbs and Rob White. This introduction to the commemorations will be chaired by Howie Firth.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: mcarthur calls for island proofed covid recovery
story: In the wake of the announcement of a new cabinet secretary for COVID recovery, Orkney MSP Liam McArthur has called for Scotland#s post-pandemic rehabilitation plan to be #island-proofed#.Mr McArthur has joined Shetland MSP Beatrice Wishart in penning a letter to the new cabinet secretary, John Swinney, appealing for the islands to be “front and centre of Scottish Government thinking”.This joint letter comes ahead of a cross party steering group due to be meet next week.The isles MSPs have shared the frustration of many of their constituents who feel that Orkney and Shetland were often seen as an “afterthought” in Scottish Government decision making processes.In the letter, the MSPs pointed to repeated announcements which updated central belt communities while neglecting to mention the dferences in restrictions for the islands.“Throughout the pandemic, there has been a frustration in the communities we represent that island needs have appeared to be an afterthought in Scottish Government decision making processes,# they wrote to Mr Swinney.#Announcements have been made with a wealth of detail about restrictions affecting central belt communities, while failing to include any mention of important dferences for island communities working under dferent rules.“This has often created confusion, not helped by the recent consultation on the easing of restrictions in the islands which was ill-conceived, poorly constructed and the responses ultimately ignored by the government.“As we look ahead to dealing with the impacts of the pandemic and shaping the recovery, it is important that this work fully reflects the islands dimension. We seek assurances, therefore, that  steps will be taken to ensure that this happens. Close collaboration with locally elected representatives, including the island authorities, will be important but we would encourage you and your officials to look at other ways of making sure this happens from the outset.“Needless to say, we would be happy to meet with you to discuss this matter in more detail.  Meantime, we wish you well in the substantial task that lies ahead and stand ready to assist, particularly in ensuring the needs of our islands are front and centre of government thinking.“We look forward to hearing from you in due course.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: orkney folk urged to join garden mammal survey
story: Summer is approaching and you may have spotted a furry friend or two roaming about your garden in recent weeks.If you have, People#s Trust for Endangered Speciesis keen to hear from you as it launches its wildle Living with Mammals survey for .PTES saw record-breaking numbers of volunteers taking part last year, thanks to more people being at home and having the time to watch wildle in their gardens and or nearby green spaces. The result was a huge increase in the number of mammal sightings, from hazel dormice on bird feeders to hedgehogs snuffling in gardens after dark.The trust believes that participation sparked a newfound appreciation, love and interest in nature for many, in all corners of the country.PTES is keen to build on this positive relationship with nature made during the past year and is asking folk to look out for and record sightings and signs of wild mammalsin their gardens or local green spaces. title: road surface dressing delayed by weather
story: newsRoad surface dressing delayed by weatherMay ,  at : pmSurface dressing work which was due to take place in Firth today was postponed due to cold weather, Orkney Islands Council has advised.According to OIC, the work on Holland Road will have to wait until warmer, drier weather s to the county.Surface dressing requires higher road surface temperatures for the materials to bed in properly — something the current cold rainy spell could compromise.The council has advised that, at this stage, the works will be delayed until at least next Tuesday. title: holyrood-minister-seeks-talks-patel-more-humane-immigration-approach
story: Data ed from the Piano meterActive meterExpired callback event.As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.Priti PatelScotlandrsquos Constitution and External Affairs Secretary is calling for an urgent meeting with Priti Patel on developing a ldquomore humane approach to immigration.Angus Robertson wrote to the Home Secretary after she said immigration removals will continue despite the protest in Glasgow which led to two men detained by immigration enforcement being released.In a speech on immigration reform earlier this week, Ms Patel responded to the incident in Pollokshields on May , saying removals were effectively what the British public have voted for. vw,vw,px, px"Protesters surrounded the van, preventing it from leaving She criticised those who sought to disrupt enforcement action, saying they ldquoshould think about whether their actions may be preventing murderers, rapists and high-harm offenders from being removed from our communities.The Home Office later insisted she was not referring to the Glasgow raid in her latter comment but was making separate points about it and people attempting to block deportation flights for foreign national offenders.There has been no suggestion either of the men targeted in the Glasgow raid are linked to any of the crimes she described. vw,vw,px, px"Angus Robertson wants a change to immigration policy In his letter, Mr Robertson said he accepts migration needs to be controlled ldquoto deter and prevent abuse, fraud and criminal activity, but that any enforcement procedures in Scotland needs to be carried out with regard to community safety and ensure ldquodignity, fairness and respect.ldquoThe immigration raid in Pollokshields, in the heart of a community celebrating Eid, a day after the First Minister warned of an upsurge of Covid- cases in the South side of Glasgow, failed that test, he wrote.ldquoIt created an unnecessary situation requiring a signicant police presence to ensure public safety.That day, protesters surrounded a Border Force van on Kenmure Street with the two Indian nationals detained inside, preventing it from leaving.The stand-off lasted several hours, with the crowd chanting ldquoleave our neighbours, let them go before Police Scotland officers released the two men on public safety grounds.Mr Robertson wrote: ldquoThe events of  May were a clear articulation of the views of the community. I donrsquot consider inflammatory and isive rhetoric suggesting that those taking action are protecting murderers, rapists and high-profile offenders is helpful.He added that the events showed people facing deportation are ldquooften valued members of communities they have been part of for many years.He continued: ldquoMany of those subject to immigration enforcement have committed no crime and are no threat to the public, having simply exhausted their appeal rights.ldquoA more humane approach to immigration enforcement is required, one which reflects the views and values of Scottish communities and does not involve the heavy-handed approach of raids which are disruptive to our communities, are inherently isive, risk public health and take up valuable police resources.ldquoI would welcome an urgent meeting to discuss how to ensure there is no repetition of the events at Kenmure Street in the future.A Home Office spokeswoman said: ldquoThe UK government continues to tackle illegal migration and the harm it causes, often to the most vulnerable people.ldquoWe are bringing forward a new plan for immigration that is fair but firm, will stop abuse of the system and remove those who have no right to be here.ldquoThe public rightly expects us to remove those who have no right to be in the UK.The simple reality is it is not possible for everyone who wants to come and live here to do so. It would not be fair to the people of this country, whose taxes fund public services and who have made it clear that they want control.copy -. title: more than 10000 shetland folk fully vaccinated with both doses
story: More than , people in Shetland are fully vaccinated with both jabs.NHS Shetland chief executive Michael Dickson announced the milestone during his Facebook broadcast on Wednesday evening.Mr Dickson said it was ldquojust fantastic.ldquoThe vaccination numbers are an enormous success, he said.ldquoItrsquos not a success for NHS Shetland, thatrsquos not why Irsquom taking about it, itrsquos a success for us as a community.ldquoBecause the vaccine means we can go back to doing the things we did be before, we can meet friends, we can meet relatives.ldquoThese are the things we miss so much andwe want to get back to them the vaccine is the best way to do it.The latest figures show that almost  per cent of over-s have had their first jab while  per cent have received both.Of the entire adult population,  per cent have received one jab and  per cent have had their second.Mr Dickson said Shetlandrsquos vaccination team had tried to contact every eligible person for the vaccine ndash and asked anyone who had not received a call to get in touch.The team is also aiming to contact people about their second doses within eight or nine weeks of their first.Compared to the mainland, Mr Dickson said Shetlandrsquos progress had been slightly faster, some of which was due to its smaller population size.He also said that as an isolated community with a more vulnerable health system it was all the more important to protect the island through vaccinations as the isles began to open up again.Mr Dickson said the progress with the vaccination nationally had brought a stark reduction in the number of cases, hospitalisations and deaths in recent weeks.But with concerns over the so-called Indian iant still looming, Mr Dickson also warned there was a risk the virus was growing again.He said the new iant had led to a signicant rise in cases, particularly in Glasgow, though thankfully it had not been accompanied by as many hospitalisations...Ive been a reporter since  at newspapers in
